reviewText:
Proof that games can be art.

One of the best videogames ever made. Smart narrative, flawless presentation, good characters, excellent dialogue. What's so good about Max Payne and makes it different than other videogames  is that it could have been done in any other medium (a novel, a movie) and still be brilliant, this puts it above other games and proof that games just like other mediums can be art.

A classic, timeless masterpiece.

reviewText:
NOTE: The game's sound is bugged due to Compatibility issues. I have provided the FIX at the bottom of this review and I do hope it helps.

TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Max Payne is the first title to the highly acclaimed Max Payne franchise. Originally developed by Remedy Games back in 2001, it has then received multiple awards for its story telling, gameplay and graphics from critics and gamers alike.

Max Payne is a third-person action game where the player takes the role of a hard-boiled, no non-sense New York City cop named, you guessed it, Max Payne, who is on a mission to avenge the death of his wife and infant daughter in the hands of vagrants who were high on a street drug named Valkyr. He sets of to find the people responsible for the production and distribution of Valkyr who he holds responsible for his family's death.

PROS:+ Story: - At first glance the story seems to be a cliché cop drama, and, yes I would agree, HOWEVER, it's the presentation, execution and overall delivery of the story that makes the original Max Payne a gem on action drama story telling.

+ Gameplay: - This was the fist game to incorporate the now popular 'Bullet Time' effect where time basically slows down allowing the player more accuracy for combat while at the same time adding theatrical spice to the gunplay. This might not be relevant to the current generation of gamers but back in 2001, it was one of the game's highest selling points.

+ Voice Acting: - Fantastic voice acting from the cast specially on the character of Max Payne with his dark humour and gritty personality.

+ Atmospheric: - The graphics for its time is top notch and delivers a very dark and depressing world that reflects the slowly changing personality of Max. From the dank and cold city streets to the surreal nightmarish realm of Max's dreams, the game stands tall on atmosphere and immersion.

CONS:- Bugged Sound for Windows Vista/7/possibly 8: - Being 13 years old, the game does suffer from compatibility issues. Gameplay wise, it functions well enough but users will encounter a bug that renders no audio in the game. (Note: LINK TO THE FIX IS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS REVIEW)

- Replayability: - Linear story is FINE, its a good way to tell a narrative story in a directed pace but Linearity does sacrifice replayability at degree because after finishing the story there is little reason to play it through a second time around. Like a good action movie, it's best to be played again after some time has passed.

- Facial Animation: - Max has a permanent facial expression where the devs tried to give him a gritty look but they just ended up making him look smug and/or constipated expression through out the game. Good thing the Comic Book cut sences are there to save the day.

CONCLUSION:Max Payne is a GREAT GAME that started a great franchise. It brought us the mainstream Bullet Time effect that most action shooter gamers has come to incorporate and embrace as a core game mechanic. It showed us a perfect blend of action and storytelling in one single game without sacrificing gameplay and mechanics.

It is a fast paced brutal 3rd person shooter that fans of the genre should not miss out on. Sale or full price, this game is worth the money and worth the time.

http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=848215

reviewText:
The original Max Payne, simply is superb.

If you enjoy a good story, and can see past some blocky graphics, this is worth a shot at a couple of $/£'s. The gameplay holds up, has the old school bullet time feature, and really hasn't dated too badly. The game is storyboard led, which means you don't have to deal with out of date facial animations!

You should be aware straight off the bat that the game is playable but has issues. You will need to download a patch which can be found in the Community Hub which changes a few audio files in to recognisable files - takes less than 2 minutes and makes the game work smoothly.

My Suggested purchase price = $3 -> $5

Notes
No Steam Achievements, No Trading Cards, No Controller Support.

reviewText:
This review is essentially a reminder....to myself.
Most of the time when I write a review, it's not just preserving a memory, it's putting a time-stamp on it.
Eventually I'll play through Max Payne again, or maybe I'll play through its sequels. When that time comes around, I want to have something to compare and contrast with. This is also so that I don't fall into making the same discussions, or focus on material that I've already covered in a previous review.

It's my personal Hell.

Speaking of Hell, Max Payne sure went through some ♥♥♥♥ didn't he? He was practically touching the American Dream, but then it all fell apart in a New York Minute. His blood-soaked tale of revenge is about as good as 3rd-person shooter storylines need to be. The plot is great, the characters are memorable, and the writing is artsy...well the good kinda artsy. It's enough to make you care, enough to make you imagine, but not so into itself that it comes off as pretentious trash. Max Payne is a bit more cultured than you'd expect from a homage to John Woo films and Noir comics.

But let's focus on the game itself. Max Payne 1 is a classic. Despite being released nearly 14 years ago, it still holds up and is great fun today (grab the widescreen fix). These days we tend to demand more from our videogames. When we pay however much it is that we're willing to, we expect our videogame to do a lot. The third-person shooter is no longer allowed to just be about shooting people, aliens, robots, mutants, or all of the above. There has to be stealth-elements, a vehicle, some turrets, and a segment where you walk slowly and wait for the exposition to finish.

Max Payne 1 is almost quaint by comparison. There's some platforming, a moment where you don't have a single gun, and stupid pet tricks (shooting switches & trip-wires). Otherwise all you're going to do be doing is shooting people. Walk into a room, bad guys appear, and you shoot them. All of the encounters are scripted, and if your eye is quick enough you can sometimes see thugs appear out of thin air. Shockingly, this standardized approach manages to maintain its high level of quality entertainment, for the 7+ hours a first-playthrough is likely to take.

Where similar games fall to the depths of mediocrity and banality, Max Payne rises above. This is precisely because it gets the primary form of interaction (shooting people) absolutely perfect. Let's start with the bullet. Your mission is to put bullets into enemies while trying to keep them out of Max Payne. There's none of that hit-scan nonsense in this game. While you can't always see the bullets as they travel, you know where they're coming from, and where they're going. These bullets travel at the same speed, cut through friend and foe alike(always a plus when bad guys accidentally shoot each other), always leave an impact. This isn't something you're liable to notice when you start the game, but over time you will acquire a new-found appreciation for bullets and the mechanics that revolve around them.

The most important strategy is to keep moving. Enemies tend to aim for your head/chest, so you're most vulnerable when standing still or getting up from a dodge. Gun-battles are short and to the point; either you die in a couple seconds, or the bad guys die in 10-15 seconds. Making shots count is important, especially if you're using the slow-motion dodge. Bullet-time can also be very effective when used properly. It's not free, and you'll get yourself killed trying to play Neo, but it's good for those times where you need a moment or two to figure things out, even during a gun-fight. Otherwise, your best strategy is liable to be F5/F9ing your way to success (though it's not so effective on the hardest difficulty).

The most interesting aspect of Max Payne is that once you think you've finally grasped how the game works, it's about to end. This is where you move onto the next difficulty, and see if you've really learned anything. When a game focuses almost entirely on one element, you will find yourself focusing on that same element as well. With every firefight you learn something new, you calculate how many shots you can make with each gun while dodging, you mull over every situation and what you could do to not only survive it, but to own it. The controls, mechanics, and everything else that makes the genre work is done in spectacular fashion.

I'd write more, but I think you should play this game and see for yourself. Although I would be shocked if you haven't played it already.

reviewText: Max Payne is a hard game. You can only play the lowest difficulty at first, and that's for a reason. You think Dark Souls is hard? ♥♥♥♥ you, it's Max Payne. Not only is Max Payne a hard game, it is an unfair game. Max Payne does not tell you that Max Payne has adaptive difficulty in addition to difficulty settings. Enemies will blow you away with a shotgun from across the room, before you even know they're there. But it's such an addictive, fun game, with such an engrossing story and so much style that once you get over your anger, you'll keep playing anyway.\n\nYou'll probably need to run it in Compatibility Mode, and the sound doesn't work right without the fix posted on the forums. It's a great game.

reviewText:
Let me tell you why this game is so darn good. And why it has dated oh so well.

Max Payne, I don't know where to start, I love this trilogy so much (Even though I love two first games much more)

Max Payne centers around...well..Max freaking Payne, a tragic character who's family has been murdered in cold blood. Max decides to go for a revenge, and one good revenge at that.

Sounds cliche? Well, things are not as they might seem, the game knows it, heck, Max knows it, the game is self-aware while still taking itself seriously, this strange blend of humor and drama makes the game date better. Max himself is a very likeable chap, you'll hear his voice a lot, and he monologues quite often.
This helps the player to understand Payne more, his personality, his feeling at that very moment. He tends to speak in a very monotone voice.

Story is being told through gameplay, comic artworks and cut-scenes, cut-scenes are not used very often, they don't tell the story most of the time actually, they're there only to show you the place and some enemies coming to get you. The game rarely takes the controls away from you.
You get to also play Max's nightmares, and nightmares they are indeed, they are most likely one of the creepiest levels you encounter in non-horror game. And yes, this indeed is quite genius. This makes us think about Max more, trying to make up our thoughts about the visuals before us.
Game has amazing voice acting, every character is voiced perfectly, the only problem some people might have is strange acting which can be seen in comics. They look silly most of the time; Sam Lake really knows how to make the weirdest faces. But then again it is most likely intentional, I wouldn't be surprised, the game really doesn't take itself too seriously, well, it does, but at the same time it laughs at itself, at its cliches etc. Not to mention Max's model has this smirk throughout the whole game, Max is most likely thinking like this:

He knows how his quest silly sounds, he knows how cliche it sounds, he knows his quest is impossible, that self awareness is what makes the game date oh-so well.

Soundtrack is top-notch as well; the main theme is truly heaven to ears as it pretty much presents Max Payne's personality.

Gameplay is extremely fun and addicting, the main mechanics this game explores are bullet time and shoot dodge. They work well and smoothly, you will not find a franchise which does this better. Even Matrix games got it wrong. The game IS challenging when you start, you'll need to learn how to use these mechanics to your own good.
Spamming shoot dodge won't get you anywhere; you can't spam it, if your bullet time runs out Max cannot use it anymore. So you better thing before using it.
Max Payne can heal himself using painkillers; he can have up to eight painkillers which he can use whenever he wants. They encourage the player to explore for them.
Game has 3 difficulties, only one being avaible at the beginning, that being the easiest one, which is still not quite easy. Luckily the game has quick saves, if that's too cheap" for you then play on the hardest difficulty which limits your saves. Even with quick save though the game is no cake walk

First off, I'd like to say that I won't talk about graphics and game physics, because obiviously they're pretty bad compared to games nowdays, I'll review this game as if I played it back then when it came out(Which unfortunately, I didn't).

Pros:

+Excellent level design - there's no set objective you need to follow, no markers or pointers that lead you exactly to where you need to go, you gotta figure out all of that on your own with hints that the level designers put it in to give you some kind of direction. I often find myself in a serious need for painkillers(the health pickups), and it feels so good to find some in a secret place. You don't really see these kind of games anymore.

+High quality voice acting(especially the narration and cutscenes, which I'll talk about later) - nothing much to say here, just that the first time I heard the narration, it was so good that I thought it was recoreded about  2-3 years ago.

+The gameplay - I've never played the game before untill now, so I didn't know what to excpect from a game this old, and I have to say that I genuinely enjoy the gameplay. Of course, the animations are a bit clanky, but it still feels good, the weapon variety, the shooting, the bullet time, everything.

+The comic book-ish cutscenes - I really love the way the story is told, instead of  advanced animations with crazy effects, each cutscene is a comic book page"

reviewText:
Nearly ten year ago the snowy rain fell on Hull like all the angels in heaven had decided to colloquially urinate at the same time. And so opened this innovative action adventure for me: I had a weekend to kill, it was snowing outside, and I had no heating. I didn't want the intellectually intensity of a strategy game, nor did I want to frenetic multitasking of a RTS. With a blanket on my legs, I sat down and completed this game in 10 hours without even a toilet break. And the first thing I did? Began again. After a toilet break.

Max Payne pitches perfect progressive difficulty. Action games shouldn't - in my busy world - kill you more than three times at the same point more than three times. You shouldn't be slugging through a game with a face as pained as Payne's permanently constipated expression. Instead you should be smiling appreciatively at just how awesome it feels to burst horizontally through a door (in slow motion) and expertly twisting through your hips as you innerringly shoot three baddies with your John Woo pistols before time jolts back into the present and all three baddies fall down at the same time. Whump.

This is not a serious game, but it is seriously evocative. The weapons, even now, feel powerful. I can remember a scene where a baddie hideing behind an apartment door unfortunately proclaims that he intends to shoot you as you come in. He doesn't, but you should, expect to leap towards him while simultaneously opening said door while unleashing a full shotgun blast to his chest that lifts him several feet in the air. You can almost hear Chuck, I mean Max, saying, not today bozo."

These scenes occur tirelessly throughout the game. Face an impossible situation. Engage bullet time (copied from the Matrix). Shoot all enemies. Read film noir comics.

While the game itself is not so serious
date: what should be a series consideration is the known (and ongoing) compatibility issues with steam. Unfortunately the download can open fail to name the weapons file correctly which can result in the game simply not starting. While I managed to get it work (on occasion) you cannot expect Steam to help you out on this one. Much better to buy on amazon.\n\nFortunately the game gleefully leads you on a deeply humorous (if a little silly) adventure once you have got the thing working. The dialogue between the baddies is priceless. Not to mention the subplot of the Lords and Ladies TV series - "My Lord! My Lady! My Lord!" - which goes on for about twenty minutes if you halt your carnage to watch the many analogue TV sets scattered throughout the game. Take this game for what it is - a romping film-noir - and you'll find an outstandingly crafted adventure that is also a piece of gaming history."

reviewText:
Back in 2001, the original Max Payne was praised for the bullet-time action (slowmo) and the realistic faces. Obviously nowadays these things won't amaze anyone anymore, so why should you play this game?

To be honest, aside from the bullet-time shootouts, Max Payne pretty much is a straightforward 3rd person shooter. What sets this game apart though is the dark and gritty story most other games do not dare to take. The dark feeling remains throughout the whole game 'till the end.

Overall Max Payne is a solid game everyone should've experienced.

reviewText:
This is a stellar game with amazing gameplay and a phenomonal story. The gameplay consists of mostly running-and-gunning, although there's one mission where you should use stealth to your advantage. The difficulty is high enough to give you a real challenge, and you must conserve painkillers to survive, and there's no cover system either. However, you can dive around in slow-motion gunfights and dodge bullets.

The story centers around a man, Max Payne who has lost his meaning of life after his family was killed in a mysterious home invasion. 3 years after the incedent, Payne is framed for murdering his best friend. Now on the run, to prove his innocence Payne must find the perpetrator, all the while uncovering a government conspiracy in a world of darkness. The story is told through various comic strips, Max's internal monologues and surreal nightmares.

The only two bad things about the game? A lack of an autosave feature and the game's audio is broken when you download it, but there should be a fix somewhere on the Steam forums, just look up Max Payne audio fix" or something. Other than that it's easily the best third-person shooter I've ever played.

"
voteText: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Max Payne is an undercover detective wanting nothing else but revenge on those who ordered the hit on his wife and killed her and their newborn baby girl. Unfortunately for him, he's been burned and framed for the murder of his best friend, a DEA agent... His rage will be unleashed on New York City criminals while evading the police. What secrets will he uncover?

Don't look at the minutes passed in Max Payne here on Steam, I happen to own the retail version. And also an italian version offered by a magazine when I was on vacations back then.

So, you may bet, I loved the plot of the game. You're going from surprise to surprise and the noir ambiance is really showing Max's state of mind. Everything is done by night or underground or in dirty buildings. Even some side characters are well-written like Mona Sax, though you should play Max Payne 2 for more secrets about her. Eeer, what? Yeah, yeah, I like Mona. But I prefer the Mona of Max Payne 2 than Max Payne. Besides, you find alliances with people you would have never thought...

The gameplay is simple: you shoot, you cover yourself, you shoot, you take painkillers to ease your pain and you use your bullet time feature to slow down time to avoid bullets and to kill more enemies. Anyway, I can't say that there is really more in Max Payne apart some puzzles (well, mainly to find your way but not the puzzles like you see in casual games). You have also a lot of weapons, interesting anyway to see Max carry so much of them. From shotgun to sniper rifle with grenade launchers, don't ask how he does. But the best is perhaps the nightmare sequence, that is separating each act.

The graphics, while looking a little old today, are also very very good. The only problem I have is the fact that Max is having always the same smiling face. I mean, this is weird at the end. But really, each level is well builded and creepy in its own: from Ragnarock to the subway, passing by the Aesir Corporation so futuristic and by the docks.

The soundtrack is also quite good. The main track is quite sad.

But the best also with Max Payne, is that the story is told as a comic, with excellent voice actors. It's allowing the story to be darker and also to have subtitles.

In other words, Max Payne was an excellent title, with an excellent plot and an excellent gameplay (the bullet feature was really helpful). It's not a wonder that it got turned into a trilogy. If you like action, you have to play Max Payne. Never regretted it back then... I should replay it on Steam too....

reviewText:

reviewText:
One of the ALL time great action games on PC. I originally purchased this back in the day when games came in boxes(in this case, a new fangled DVD jewel case, complete with a Max Payne mousepad). To say that it's stood the test of time since then is an understatement: this game is no less a joy to play today, as it was day1.

Plenty of available mods, skins, and latest OS support(widescreen fixes etc) are available, so don't hesitate to pick this up.

For anyone who doesn't know: this game plays out much like a film noir comic book. Yes, the dialog is campy, but so were 99.99% of those old detective noir movies. If you're a fan of dialog(think Deadwood on HBO), characters, and action, then this should be a no brainer buy.

reviewText: Gritty, and action packed! This game introduced the revolutionary slow motion capture in videogames like the movies that the Matrix first started. Max Payne is cop on the run after being framed for a murder he did not commit is being chased by fellow cops who want revenge and the mob who know he personally have had a hand in putting away others just like them. reviewText:
TL; DR version: classic game, great story, PC = definitive version, <3

One of my favorite games of all time!

This isn't remastered in any way, this is the original PC version, so if you're playing it for the first time... this is a 2001 title! If you're here feeling nostalgic, skip reading reviews and just buy it :) If you haven't played Max Payne previously, please keep its age in mind when judging it for the first time.

Though the graphics may not, the story, however, will always stand the test of time. Your wife and daughter are murdered within the first ten minutes, which is the basis of the mystery you must now unravel. Meanwhile, outside, the worst blizzard in years envelops New York City. The atmosphere matches Max's desperation, breathing life into otherwise usual settings like rooftops, or the docks, as you mow down foes in winter coats huddling around a trashcan fire. There isn't a dull moment in the game, whether Max is fighting armies of baddies, interacting with memorable villains (and allies) or losing himself in his own nightmares. The story gets an A+ in my book and an A+++ when compared to the trash passed off as game plots nowadays.

The dialogue can be both fantastic and cheesy. Fantastically cheesy? Whatever you think of it, it is fitting to Max Payne's comic book style. There are cutscenes, but more often there are panels with speech bubbles and illustrations. I'm not sure if this was a budget or style decision, but it quickly became the series' trademark. There are lines, both funny and serious, which my friends and I quote to this day (As in... you cry a lot?").

The shooting mechanics are fine. At the very least it has aged MUCH more gracefully than other old shooters. You don't have to aim precisely
date: just point in an enemy's general direction and shoot. It's not realistic. You can snipe people with dual submachine guns from across a rooftop
voteText: 5 grenades and a grenade launcher all at once. You get a great arsenal by the way
helpfulPercent: and new weapons are steadily introduced throughout. Ammo is abundant. Painkillers are plentiful. I truly believe Max Payne was designed in a way to let you enjoy its story without getting stuck on this or that.\n\nI've also played Max Payne on several platforms: first on PS2
votesHelpful: then original Xbox and finally PC. I play it every few years. PC is the definitive version. In addition to not having to dust off your questionable old system
votesTotal: which is stuffed in a closet somewhere (or at least in my case it is)
votesFunny: it runs smoothest on PC
commentsCount: and there are little things you will notice (for example
column17: comic book font used in the PC version was converted to a generic font in the console versions).\n\nIt's worth the $9.99 Steam is asking
column18: and it's on sale all the darn time so there's no reason not to revisit Noir York City
column19: as Max calls it.\n\nAlso note: there's a slight compatibility issue
column20: and the audio won't work with Windows 7 initially. Check the workshop for a simple sound patch that takes moments to install and works flawlessly. Just follow the instructions exactly and you're good to go! Happy gaming!"

reviewText: The film noir aesthetic works to its advantange, making up for the lower points and weaker moments in the story. Payne isn't a very complex character (nothing in this actually is) and not even that likeable to a degree. reviewText:
This game is >AMAZING<

Before we talk about the gameplay lets look at the plot.

Max Payne came home once from the job. He found out his Wife and Child have been murdered. He becomes a vigilante to hunt down to those who killed his family. Hunted by both the cops and the mafia.

Gameplay: 9/10

The shooting mechanics are the main part of Max Payne that makes it great. It has a bullet time system that is very useful in tight situations. The guns in this game are also decent. They are not to Overpowered or too Weak. The enemies have a good amount of balance. Enemies can be very easy to kill but Max Payne too. Enemies that hold Desert Eagles, Shotguns or Ingrams (Uzi's) can easily kill you in medium to close range. There is 3 Chapters in the game. Each of them have missions. It depends on the players skill that these missions can be very short or long. All in all the Gameplay is amazing and does not have a lot of negatives. The only negatives I can point out is that unskippable cinematics and some parts of the mission that is confusing. Great gameplay
-------
Sound: 8/10

The sound in this game is tremendous. It has a great soundtrack, especially the theme. It fits the Noir setting of the game. The other soundtracks are also good. There is some 80s vibe music in some action scenes that reminds you of those Fun 80s action flicks and there is also some dark music in some parts of the game to make you feel either uneasy or expecting something thats coming. Good soundtrack
---------
Graphics

For its time (Early 2000s): Very Good!
Right now (2014): Decent

This can be judged either way. If you expect the same type of Graphics as Max Payne 3, You will be a little disappointed. The Graphics are old but you can't judge it as it came out in an era where Graphics where still being improved.

If you do not care about Graphics (Which is me) you wouldn't mind it at all. It will be a fun experience even with the old Graphics and doesn't make it bad.
-------

Story: 7/10

The story is amazing. It sounds like those simple revenge films but takes a step further with the action mixed into it while keeping the thriller and noir feeling. It has great characters and it is well paced. Story is shown in a Graphic Novel styles to show the plot progressing. It is a sad story about a man who lost his family. Nice and well done storyline. There is a few negative things though. SPOILERS""SPOILERS""SPOILERS". The ending is has a Cliffhanger feeling. The Valkyr is not really explained and some characters are just taken down easily. Specially the main villian who is introduced half-way but then wasted into a helicopter crash. No boss battles or anything
date:
just some explosion and WOOP! villian is gone. It should have gotten a boss battle at least.

OVERALL: 9/10

+ Good story
+ Very good Game Mechanics
+ Good price if you ask me
+ Nice soundtrack

- Short gameplay time if you are skilled enough leaving you a little for more
- SPOILERS< Ending is leaves a few questions unanswered
recommended:
also disappointing villian end

Thanks for reading! Cheers and buy this game right now!!

"

reviewText: The original Max Payne was almost a landmark title. It combined amazing storytelling devices from old detective stories and graphic novels, with bullet time straight from Hong Kong action cinema. Combine that with 1-1 PC controls and a surprisingly good soundtrack, you have a piece of art all modern action games aspire to.

reviewText: No other game has ever made me feel in the skin of a character so deeply like Max Payne. Amazing story, setting, soundtrack, cinematics and beautiful graphics, especially when you take in consideration it was released in 2001. It's a must have for any serious gamer. Max Payne is not without its flaws, though. The gameplay leaves a lot to be desired, with repetitive puzzles, predictable AI behaviour and overly simplistic game mechanics. Still, the reason I play this game over and over again is not for its gameplay but for its story. In a way, you could say it's like an interactive film noir, and that's exactly what makes it worth every single second you play it.

reviewText:
Despite the fact that this game needs to be run in compatability mode for Windows ME/2000 (I'm on Windows 8.1 64-bit), and that it needed a quick sound patch (2 seconds to google and install) - this game ran really well and as intended.

The actual gameplay is, as to be expected, very dated and from a different era of gaming (aka its a little chaotic in the sense you can get 1 shot by a pistol to the head, if you're unlucky - and sure enough, this is realistic, but still a bit dumb if you open a door and die instantly because of it (NPCs are crazy-fast on the trigger)). The narrative and voice acting did make me want to barf a lot, due to the horrible production quality (even for the time it was made in), but it was not a bad game overall as it had a lot of funny/interesting chapters throughout the game - and being one of the classics, its one you don't want to miss.

I would also say that, no matter your stance on playing old games, if you plan on playing Max Payne 3, pull through and play this and the second - it still has a lot of nice moments even by today's standards.

Having played both this and the second one way back in the day, I can only say that it was just as enjoyable then as it is now.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 9/10

I love me some shooter, especially if it's Max Payne. I picked it up in a bundle with The Fall of Max Payne for a ridiculously cheap price, somewhere in the region of £2.50 or something. While I haven't played much of it so far, due to not having much time, I can tell you from console and PC experience that this is a solid port of a solid game. The cutscenes are great, in the form of a comic book strip which blends very well with the dark storyline.

The shooting is awesome and the bullet time is so much fun, the only problem I have with the game is the quick saving. It was originally binded to F5, but on a HP Envy, you can't use any of the F keys without holding CTRL or something. Makes it very annoying to save, however that was easily fixed in the options menu. However, I found myself saving after I killed any enemy in fear of going too far back.

Other than that small nitpick, the game is great. A good story, good mechanics and the sound quality is good. Bravo on a  good PC port Valve!

reviewText: I find this game superior to its sequel.\n\nThe strange thing about Rockstar is that they apply truckloads of polish to any product they get their hands on, but they lose all sight of fun in the process. There are more enemies to kill in the first third of Max Payne than there are in the entirety of MP2, and it's noticeably more satisfying in this installment, because Remedy know how to allow their level design to synergistically complement their control scheme and gameplay. Max Payne 2 lost a lot of that magic.

reviewText: Incredible graphics, a compelling storyline, and an immersive experience. All of these features are expertly combined in Max Payne, creating a candidate for the best game of 2001.Pure, unadulterated, hard-core, ♥♥♥ kicking, pop a cap in ya' ♥♥♥ action and gunplay. Max Payne levels it’s .45 and sends stealth quivering back to the marketing table, where it belongs. And it’s all the better for it.Even the death sequences are pretty cool, as the game slows down, zooms in on the hero and shows him getting gunned down by a hail of lead.There's an air of amusing determination to everything Max does. All the murdering is very satisfying for that reason.Max Payne is rife with gunplay that's almost indescribably beautiful to watch--and yet actually playing it is even better.

reviewText:
Max Payne... woah, where to begin?

I will start by saying it's one of my first PC games that I've played, back in 2002. The game is EXCELLENT! Even compared to today's standard. Sure, the graphics is a  bit outdated, there are some sound issues but nothing game breaking that can't be fixed.

Compared to its time, Max Payne was a step ahead, great graphics, physics and special effects. The story line is very good and intriguing, the end chapters are full of surprises and mind♥♥♥♥ moments. I can say that this is the best game in the entire series, probably also the hardest. I have beaten it countless of times on ALL difficulties, including New-York minute!

Has a very high replayability value. Voice acting - excellent. Cutscenes - again excellent. Do not miss out on this cult classic, worth every dime!

Max Payne is a must play for any action gamer, with a memorable story and superb gameplay this is one to  surely enjoy!\n\nYou will also need to install the Sound Fix and the Widescreen Fix for modern systems. reviewText:
Max Payne... The beginning of a franchase too amazing to be missed.
With a script blended with a way so darn cool naration that made the story way too awesome for its time, this game set the flag for a new awesome style of detective/police drama concept in video games.
The gameplay and action is fantastic (and pretty damn difficult at some points) with OMGWTF♥♥♥♥YEAH shooting gameplay and a slo-mo bullettime that makes it even more eygasmic. The effects and graphics are neat for its time.
What's also interesting about this game is that it is different in some levels from the other Max Payne games out there at the moment.
There's some unique humorous and other mind♥♥♥♥ing moments (whick can't be mentioned due to spoilers) that don't exist in the other games in teh same way they are introduced here.
Also the character's face is a whole different face model. Although Timothy Gibbs (Max Payne 2) and James McCaffrey (Max Payne 3) had quite some face structural similarities the face model of the main character in Max Payne 1 is based on Sam Lake in honor of his work as he was the writer of the actual original story.
It is very important to mention that the naration and voice acting is absolutelly AfreakinMAZING. With James McCaffrey giving his voice through the entire franchise (so far) Max is a character unique beyond comparison.


Please note that there are compatibility issues with the late OSs (just like most old games do) after installing.
here you will have everything resolved: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1858303

Absolutelly recommended. If you are a fan of the genre I urge you to start this franchise.
And if you haven't played the first Max Payne but you did play any of the other two, unless you have issues with old game graphics, you must try this no matter what.

reviewText:
A great classic, replayed it only to relive my childhood. Slow-motion/bullet time are some of the best effects and the ones that define this game.

Nice comic-book like storyline, filled with tragedy and thrill, too bad the voice acting (if there is any) bugs there sometimes.

Probably due to games becoming more player friendly nowadays and making us soft, I can say the game took me longer to finish as expected, on easiest settings died quite a lot and couldn't really progress without constantly saving, there is a lot of shooting combat all over the game which requires you to focus a lot on killing and not getting hit.

The bots are really bots, most of the times they know where you are and aim exactly at you, no matter the difficulty, it can become frustrating sometimes, but it's rewarding in it's own way.

EDIT: I wanted to add the fact that this memorable game was a source of inspiration for my cosplay http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=201596535

reviewText:
I remember first playing this at my neighbour's house on his Playstation 2. This is a action-noire video game where you take the role of Max Payne, a cop falsely accused and his family murdered horrifically. You watch him descend into madness slowly and how he copes through this, all the while spraying bullets at the people responsible to the tragedy that has befallen him.

From popping pain killers to cope and as a gameplay mechanic for health, due to him going lucid via bullet time to kick ♥♥♥, to plain out reliving nightmares that you must go through, this game is great. Also, instead of cinematics it's comic book panels. The entire video game is seeped with noire and is an incredible journey.

I highly recommend this game to people looking for a fun action packed game that is challenging with a good story and a character that is likeable. Save often, as it's not an easy ride.

reviewText:
Max Payne is one of the best games I've ever played.


I'd start with the story, but that is an entire review in itself. I'll just say 12/10 story :)


The gameplay is just so amazing. The game always manages to keep you on the edge of your seat. It gives you just enough ammo and painkillers to stay alive as long as you don't make any mistakes. The slightest slip up can send you back to your last save.

Speaking of saving, let me introduce you to the F5 key. This is my best friend. As you could probably guess, it's the quicksave button. You will probably die A LOT in this game, depending on how good you are. Just remember to press F5 before you open a door and you won't have really anything to worry about.

Also, have a walkthrough open while you play this. There are some levels where to progress, you need to do the most RANDOM thing, such as shoot the top off of a propane tank, try to open a locked door, or even break a few boxes. Just be warned.

Anyways, 9/10, one of my personal favorites, definitely worth the buy.

reviewText: It doesn't look very good today, and we've seen the central mechanic copied a thousand times since, but this is a classic of action gaming that's proven very influential over the years, for better or worse. Even if it hasn't aged the best, the copious helping of noir style and dead-serious melodrama mixed with weird humour make this one still worthwhile, and I recommend running through it as part of a full trilogy run.\n\nIt comes from a simpler time where shooters could just be about shooting everyone, with no vehicle sections, no hacking minigames, no rpg elements, no sandbox elements, no moral choices, no collectibles, no quicktime events, no... well, you get the idea. It can seem like a relic today, but I appreciate the simplicity and devotion to doing one thing and doing it well. Coupled with one of my favourite video game protagonists, and this one remains a fond memory even when played today.

reviewText:
This is without a doubt one of the greatest games of all time. Max Payne 1 is a third person action thriller video game that was developed by Remedy Entertainment and published by Gathering of Developers in July 2001. You play as Max, who is a NYPD detective who comes home one day to find that his family has been murdered. He then attempts to avenge the murder of his family.

This game has a very gritty neo-noir style and it also uses a graphics novel to tell the story in full detail. This game comes with incredible atmosphere that is very depressing and goes along perfectly with the ambient soundtracks. This is also one of the first games to feature the bullet time affect that was popularised by the matrix. I fully reccomend playing this game even today, this is just one of those games that never gets old.

If I was to pick a game that I had the greatest experience playing, it would be this one. I remember being around 9 years old, having a computer that could barely run this game. I bought this game for just £2 at a used games store without knowing anything about this game. I got home and holy ♥♥♥♥ I was suprised. This game just seemed to be utterly perfect to me and before I knew it I found myself getting deeper and deeper into what some gamers call the zone" I have had this with other games
date: but never like I did with this one. Everything other than this game started to fade away as I was playing it in a dark room. it got so strong that it was almost like this game became my entire reality and it was the only thing that existed in the universe. It was so strange
recommended: but it was probably one of the greatest experiences of my life."

The cinematic gameplay, the gritty story, the noir-inspired aestethics - the game has a timeless quality to it that you rarely find in old titles. There's something about playing as a rogue cop who guns his way through crazy mobsters and corrupt government agents that I can't quite put my finger on which makes it so memorable. Maybe its Max's inner monologues about his sense of right and wrong. Perhaps it's the difficult gameplay and the shoot first or get shot" attitude of the combat which really brings out the rush in the player. Whatever it is

reviewText:
About The Game:
Max Payne is a 3rd person shooter based around mobsters, drug addicts & drug dealers that run rampant in the streets of New York City & you as Max Payne the cities Ex Cop" which put most of them away for their crimes.

A rather large & compelling story with major plot twists around each corner. You'll need a lot of clarity in your head to grasp the reality of this well written and planned out story that is "Max Payne".

The Story:
Max Payne's story is set around the player Max Payne who is a Police Officer in the New York Police Department
date: you're 1 of the biggest cops in the department because of how many cases you've solved and how many criminals you've put away
recommended: of course with all the popularity from the good guys the bad guys also see it fit to use you as their scapegoat for a very chilling & deep story.\n\nMax Payne is stuck centered in a mob hit which has his Wife & Baby murdered in cold blood
hoursPlayed: this leaves Max with a bad case of depression & drug abuse
voteText: While Max is on his first job back at the force
helpfulPercent: Max ends up once again getting stuck in another situation that has his partner killed & him being framed as the gunman
votesHelpful:
this causes him to lose his job at the police force & leaves him on the run as a wanted criminal.

With major twists around every corner and a very dark and unnerving story you're going to need to experience every second of it to understand truely how the protaganist feels.

The Gameplay:
Max Payne's gameplay is set around shooting
votesTotal: shooting and more shooting
votesFunny: there's not much sections in the game that don't rely on you killing someone or something. But of course if you were in Max's situation you'd be out for revenge for who set you up & murdered your family too.\n\nThe gunplay in Max Payne is very iffy & doesn't feel the best
commentsCount:
at times the guns feel too useless & you spend more time retrying sections till you get them right! This gets really frustrating & will often have you quit every half an hour or so.

The use of Bullet Time in this game is one of the cooler features in the franchise.
This game is where "Bullet Time" started for the gaming community only after the Matrix movies started it for the movies. (Props to Remedy for bringing this awesome feature to reality).

Max Payne is one of the few games that doesn't use Quick Saves & Checkpoints so make sure you save frequently or you're going to be starting from the beginning of the game quite a lot!

The Verdict:
Max Payne 1 it self is not a bad game
column17: Remedy is one of the best companies i've ever seen when it comes to story telling gameplay
column18: from Max Payne to Alan Wake they're flawless in story with very little to no plot holes & they also have very solid gameplay to boot.\n\nThe problem i have with Max Payne 1 is that it's quite frustrating that the weapons feel useless & the NPC enemies will generally rush at you in order to kill you rather than duck behind cover & wait for you to come to them. It feels a bit cheap and because you have no defence when they get in close to you

Combat is very nice with Bullet Time but without Bullet Time it can be quite hard to kill the enemies so make sure you save it for when you need it.

Hang onto as many "Pain Pills" as you can because they're your source of health & they're quite scarce and of course without them expect to die alot.

Max Payne is such a great game from it's seriously dark and grim story to it's fantastic Bullet Time & Character Development to the enemies having very interesting and creative dialogue

reviewText:
Max Payne really is quite the video game. It is one of those video games that makes us question what a video game truly is. Almost all the cutscenes are done in a graphic novel style literally going from one page to the next after the charecters have spoken. It is very interesting and unique to the point where I wanted to play just to get to the next scene sort of like how I would want to play MGS games just to get to the next scene. However unlike MGS the gameplay is extremely unique. It is a third person shooter that places Max in the middle of the screen with a crosshair in the very center of the screen. Most people who play this game rave about how fun it is to use the bullet time effect to take out enemies. I agree that it is extremely fun and sometimes difficult to do. You use quick saves in the game which you NEED TO USE unless you are a god at the game then you will not be getting through that many levels without dying. Ofcourse there is an autosave feature but it is pathetic how often it is used. With quicksaves you will find yourself saving before a fight then going into the fight and most likely dying in which you will rethink everything like where you aimed, how you entered the area or what gun you used.

Let me just put it this way. I was up late exausted playing this game just desperatley wanting to get to the next scene.

I think the only bad things about the game (gameplay wise) really are the underpowered weapons or not knowing where to go or what to do at times.

Now the bad things about the game in general that are not really related to the gameplay is how Max just all of a sudden becomes a mass murderer after his family is killed. Max never talks about how hard it is to shoot and kill people just to get to the person responsible for the murder. There is also quite a lot of blood and very sexual things in the game but I think that is to be expected when the game is advertised as a Noir story.

Overall this game is fantastic and if you are not bothered by anything that I have mentioned in the last two paragraphs you are crazy not to be playing this game as soon as humanly possible (Unless you are one of those unfortunate enough to have a computer that will not start this game up due to the direct X 8 requirment)

UPDATE: After updating my driviers to catylyst 14.12 for my AMD 6670 graphics card and running the game in compatibility mode Windows 98/ME I have got the game to work on my Windows 7 64 bit computer. I had to use the audio fix afterwards and I was running the game fine.

reviewText:
Don't let the inital lack of sound fool you (Google the sound patch for it and it'll all be fine), this game is timeless. Having just recently started getting into video game franchises, I decided to give Max Payne a try (it was bundled with Max Payne 2 for only a few bucks!). Boy, was it a good choice.

Due to my being accustomed to third person shooters like Uncharted, it was definitely jarring going into the game and realising there's no cover and the enemies have no propensity for self-preservation. And Max is very easy to kill (meaning in the gameplay, not in the storyline). This made things extremely interesting and fast paced. The AI could be dumb a lot, but I mean AI wasn't what it was now. Nevertheless, these elements made for very actiony gameplay. Although the game is set in the 90s, the atmosphere, the vehicles and the dress of some of the characters made it all seem like a proper film noir. The storyline is intricate and very entertaining and the graphic novel scenes are very well-voiced (for the most part).

And of course, I can't do this without mentioning bullet time. Springing forward or sideways in slow motion to take on your enemies is so satisfying. Best of all, the bullets are all rendered, even shot from your shotgun, meaning it's not just hitscan and you can see the bullets  land. It's really cool.

All in all, the game is cheap and very much worth it, even after all these years.

9/10

reviewText:
Max Payne is a classic 'black-and-white' noir tale. It sits among the trendiest of trendsetters and the most stylish of stylish games without compromising substance - indeed, playing it again recently I realised it has aged fantastically; the story and gameplay both hold up, the controls are intuitive, and the revolutionary 'bullet-time' mechanic is still a lot of fun - something to attribute to its stylishness and ability to age well is the fact that segments of the story told at the beginning of each chapter via comic book form are beautifully illustrated and voiced to set the atmospheric noir vibe for the next chapter.

tl;dr this game is a primordial soup of excellence

Play it if you haven't already, please.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I finally played through this game. I remember playing the demo years ago when it was new, but I thought the theme was too dark and didn't play it.  I figured it would be easier to play now, but the beginning of the game is as dark and creepy as ever, although it does provide you with strong motivation.

The game makes liberal use of bullet-time from The Matrix.  Heck, it even steals the hotel lobby scene right out of the movie, which is a blast to play.  The effect is done masterfully.  At first, it seems like this may make the game too easy, but before long,  you realize you'll need it to survive.  There is no health regen, only a limited supply of pain pills you have to hunt for.

The game was released in 2001, so the graphics look dated now, but you can tell they were very good for the time.  The game supports widescreen resolutions, but it stretches out the picture.  You'll be better off picking a 4:3 resolution with the same height as your monitor.  If you have sound problems, setup the game with Alchemy (SoundBlaster only) or look for a user patch.  The game clocks in at only 10 hours"

reviewText: This game has aged incredibly well. INSANELY well. It's a blast to play, the graphics are rarely an issue, and good storytelling doesn't get worse over time. Max Payne's signature jump...things are always satisfying, and slaughtering the infinite hordes of sleazy New Yorkers is as satisfying as any modern TPS, with a dark, comic book story to boot. Note, this game is DARK. Like, really, really dark. As far as I could see, there wasn't a single human (apart from Max's wife, who is dead) who wasn't either severely psyschologically disturbed, depressed, psychotic, self-centered, or just an all-around slimeball. There are no happy endings, and Max knows it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
'They were all dead. The final gunshot was an exclamation mark on everything that had led to this point. I released my finger from the trigger, and it was over.'

If there's one video game opening that has never left me, it's Max Payne. The grim, almost relieved voice speaking out over New York City from a top the Aesir Tower gripped me from the start.

Max Payne is part video game, part comic and a proud piece of video gaming history.

The best thing about Max Payne, other than the protagonist's name obviously, is bullet time. Slow down time to show off your moves and make every shot count.

Probably the only flaw of Max Payne was that it has to end. The average player should be able to clear the game within 7 hours quite easily on the first play through. Harder difficulties and a time trial mode are unlocked following the first play through and will test your abilities.

11/10 would noir again.

reviewText:
Classic noir storyline complete with drug lords, crime bosses, evil corporations, secret societies, crazy conspiracies and crooked coppers. Max is a vigilante undercover cop who goes rogue while on a quest for revenge. The writing is filled with tasty, if drippy, noir-style metaphors that would make your literature professor cringe like a vegetarian bat at an all-night salad bar...

Must play this game with liberal use of quicksaves (F5), as the bullets often come from surprising and peculiar directions (hilarious, actually). And use Max's slo mo effect to shoot the bad guys while diving across the room double-wielding smgs -- just like Chow Yun-fat in the movie, Hardboiled."

Dated and quirky
date: this quaint third-person shooter is just plain entertaining and fun."

reviewText: Quick-save happy action game squarely of the old school variety. At the time of release there was just nothing else like Max Payne. The Matrix was fresh in the minds of the masses. System Shock 2, Half-Life, Deus Ex, had all been released. PC gaming couldn't get any better. Or so we thought.\n\nControls may seem wonky to youngins raised on the buttery smooth engines of late. Mechanics may seem unpolished if you're used to a skill ceiling in reach of everyone". Max Payne can both challenge and frustrate you. Gameplay-as-story was new and had only been woven succesfully into a handful of titles. It stands as a great example of a "pure" game
date: hitting all the highs the medium has to offer. It hasn't aged quite as gracefully as other classics
recommended: but strap into a comfy chair with at least a few hours to spare
hoursPlayed: turn the lights down and your sound up and prepare to enjoy an excellent affair of cinematic gaming in the dark underworld of a frozen New York City."

How could anyone NOT recommend it? It's a classic. Sure, MP 3 is praised by many, but this, the first one, is the real deal. Great noir story taking place in snowy New York, all alone against tens of enemies, seeking for revenge. Well-made comic style segments, impressive voice acting, varied environment and a good arsenal of weapons to use. Action game lovers who haven't played this treasure yet should do something about it, otherwise they can't call themselves real gamers.

When the original Max Payne came out in 2001, it was hailed for its storytelling, visuals, and gritty noir setting. The game's incredible technical accomplishments and its original play mechanics all combine to make it one of the very finest shooters ever made.
This has to be one of the best crime thriller games i have played, the story is so driven even when there is no voice acting for Max Payne,\ni would highly recommend this game to anyone.

The desciption of this game is as follows: Max Payne is a man with nothing to lose in the violent, cold urban night. A fugitive undercover cop framed for murder and now hunted by cops and the mob. Max is a man with his back against the wall, fighting a battle he cannot hope to win. Prepare for a new breed of deep action game. Prepare for pain...

At a glance that discription seems like a revenge story that we've all seen before and for the most part it is, however where this game really stands out is in its delivery, tone and of course gameplay. While the game may be over a decade old I can say as someone who played Max Payne in 2014 and 2001 that it has aged very well and is worth a look for newcomers and people who are interested in replaying the game.

reviewText: Very Good game, recommend to everyone! Enjoyable and Unbelievable Story. 9.4/10.

One of my favorite games of all time. Max Payne is a shooter way ahead of it's time that takes you through a long, dark, well written adventure.

Each level is long with lot's of work and detail put into it. You have a slow-motion meter and you can watch each bullet hit its target in your firefights and every item in this game reacts differently to bullets and shotgun shells(Televison sets explode with electricity, walls spark and spit out debris, metal clunks and sparks, fire hyrdrants emit foam and the list goes on!) making for some EXTREMELY satisfying gunplay.

Plenty of humor and detail thrown into the game, if you wait before confronting certain enemies, they'll have different (and oftentimes, hilarious) scripted conversations that are worth listening to. As the sh** hits the fan later on in the game, the enemies and levels get crazier and more menacing all the way to the final level taking place in the heavily guarded and delightfully long and huge(very funny) Aesir Corporation building.

An all-around great game. My only beef with the game on Steam is the fact that when I play it, there is almost always no sound while playing. There is a patch you can download, but being the pc noob that I am I don't know how to do it and make it work ):
(However Max Payne 2 which, in my opinion is almost as good and better in certain aspects, works just fine. And as Max Payne 1 and 2 are both ten dollars on Steam, I highly recommend you purchase the 15 dollar bundle that includes both games.)

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Rv5_R4nfv8

Max Payne. Maximum pain. His name hides his destiny, never to find peace, to lose everyone he cares about, constantly to be in pain and always be on the edge of life and death. This is the tragic story of the title character of the revolutionary Max Payne.

In one faithful night, everything he loves is gone in a blink of an eye and the world around him crumble. Arriving home he find his baby daughter and wife killed by junkies, under the influence of a new found drug on the streets of NY, called Valkyre or just V. After the funeral Max transfer to DEA and goes undercover, determine to find where the drug comes from. Only two agents, Alex and B.B. knows who he is. Three years later, Max finally have break on the Valkyre case. He recieve a messege from B.B. to meet Alex. Max have a bad feeling about this and he wasn't wrong. Alex get killed and he takes the blame for the murder. With nothing left to lose, Max takes the path of vengeance. He is been chased by everyone – police, mobsters, freaks and so on. This wild chase is happening in the middle of huge winter storm, as if it comes end of the world. From here follows twist and turns, betrayls, meeting with insane villians, bad guys helping you with information, corruptions, blackmail and so on. The story is one of the best things here. It's written by Sam Lake, who is the face of Max. The script is full of metaphors and references to scandinavian mythology. It's brilliantly written.

Cutscene are great and original. They are looking like graphic novel with neo-noir vibe and the voice of James McCaffrey make them even more memorable. Because of the moderate budget, Sam Lake is the face of the main characters and friends and colleagues are other people in the game. The cutscenes are filled with the inner monologs of Max, from which we find out the story and his mental state.

Even so many years later all this is still kind of impressive. But what is most memorable and revolutionary is in the gameplay section. The thing i'm talking about is bullet-time. It gives you more time to react and make more accurate shots. You can see to the silhouette of Max an hourglass. There is shown how much bullet-time you have. With a press of a button everything slows down and you can even see where the bullets fly. If you dive in it takes little part of it, so you have to decide how to use it. The hourglass drains quickly and the only way to fiil it is to kill enemies without using bullet-time. You have to use it wisely, because slowing down time is essential for reaching the end. The game is highly inspired by Hong Kong action movie, especially those of John Woo.

The game is old school and doesn't have regenerating health. You restore it by the most logical thing for the game – painkillers. You find them in spread around the levels. Sometimes they are not in obvious places.

The feeling of using bullet-time and blast through small group of bad guys is awesome.You are almost invulnerable. But you are not. Max life is fragile and even on the lowest difficulty, you can die in a blink of an eye. The game is hard, but fair. She will  kick your ♥♥♥ right from the start and ask do you want more. Most of the times when you die, it's player fault. Some enemies are cheaply placed and you don't have enough time to react. So quick save is alway an option. I don't want to know how is in the higher difficulties.

Max have substantial, but fairly standard arsenal of weapons – pistols, shotgun, double barrel shotgun, assault rifle, uzi, granade launcher, granades, sniper, Molotov and my favorite – Jackhammer. In close range is irreplaceable. The only weapon i don't like is the shotgun. The reloading speed is slow and i often die, when i use it. Here you can find one interesting and innovative thing. When you shoot with the sniper, the camera follows the bullet. Sound familiar? Few years later this will be the main feature in Sniper Elite.

The level design is awesome. They fairly diverse – abandone buildings, harbor, mansion and so on. Some places are even turn in to a brothel. There you can see, especially in the abandon buildings, the darkside of NY. The atmosphere is dark, grimm and depressing, particularly when you see the consequences on people using Valkyre. Death is above them and waiting to collect their souls. There are other more bright places like mansion, skyscraper and so on. But there heavily armed men are waiting for you. There are two different level. Little anoying to navigate, but they are not long. They are dreams, representing the mental state of Max, his fears, desires and the guilt he feels all the time. Dark and confused like himself.

The graphics are bad, but it's 14 year old game. This is the biggest problem here. Human models are not pretty to look at and not different enough. When you take in account release date, modest budget of 3 milion dollars for four years and the small Remedy team, it's not suprising. But in the end the game sold 7,5 million copies.

14 years later the sound design is still impressive. Guns doesn't sound bombastic, they are not too loud. When using pistol, you hear pistol.

The voice acting is fantastic. Even people with small roles are doing great job, but most memorable is of James McCafferey. There is an actior voicing one of the bosses, lunatic using V, can make you shiver, when you hear him talking.

You will remmember the music in Max Payne, especially the singnature music theme. Deep beat, followed by piano and little bit later guitar and drums can be heard. All this sets the mood for the sad and dark story of Max. The others are also good. Energetic tracks with pinch of tension in the style of 80's action movies. Some places don't have music playing and this just adds to the atmosphere. Phenomenal soundtrack. When you consider the budget of Remedy, all of this is incredible. Modern games should take a notes.

This game is classic and everyone have to play. It even run great on Windows 7. You have the feeling you are in John Woo movie, where hero pour a rain of bullets and skillfully avoid them. Despite that the graphics didn't age  well, every person have to see the roots of this series and the beginning of bullet-time. It doesn't matter how other games call it. The foundation is laid here. The story and gameplay are still great. Fantastic soundtrack, great and inovative gameplay, original and interesting cutscene, superb action. Here is also laid the foundation of one of the most beloved games from me – Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne. I highly recommend it.

After spending a long time ♥♥♥♥♥ing at AMD to get the drivers to work (12.8 was the last working drivers till 13.4 CCC released), and fixing the sound.. Man was it worth the $5 I paid for 1 and 2.\n\nA much better game than Max Payne 3" .  Which should have been named "Max Payne: Blackwater Agent  Style Contract For Rich Idiots" ."

Even though published already in 2001, Max Payne still keeps on rocking. Max Payne offers an interesting and dark twisted plot which keeps you quessing until you reach the very end of the game. As a side note, the developers of Max Payne had decided to create easter eggs and other interesting visual appearences, which combined with the awesome story the game has to offer leaves you willing to play the game through yet another and maybe the third time.

Gameplaywise Max Payne is basically a run and shoot game with a very little variation between the firefight scenes you encounter. The range of usable weapons in the game is pretty small and the amount of bullets you will have to consume to kill the enemies is absolutely ridiculous. Also the enemies have a bad habit to come out of the blue or suddenly throw grenades which are almost impossible to evade within the given time. With that being said the gameplay of Max Payne is quite fast-paced and needs to be played with a great amount of concentration.

Despite the negative sides of the gameplay, there is also something good to say about it. The level design of the game is pretty unique and really one of those things which arouses the original Max Payne-like feelings in the player while playing the game through. The voice acting in the game is great and the facial expressions the enemies as well as Max have on their faces are rather funny. Also the controllability of Max's moves is very well done and the fact that there is so much awesome mods made for Max Payne gives it some added value.

Overall when you get used to playing Max Payne, it isn't that hard to beat on any level. I have played Max Payne through once before I owned it on Steam. After I got the Steam version, I made three more playthroughs, with every given difficulty option. And guess what? I just cannot regret the time spent playing on this obvious game. After the first (Steam version) playthrough I found myself enjoying outdated graphics, some visual appearences and the certain things in the actual gameplay the game has to offer. When you find your kung fu being strong enough this is your best bet. With no doubt you will not regret it!
aged well, amazing writing, you can't recreate max's expression without botox, tough gunplay, but sadly lacks in replay value. 9/10 - wish i played and beat sooner.

the game that became the standard for third person shooters and put bullet time in games on the map.  sure the game feels kinda dated today,  but sill hella fun.  and of  course can't forget the ICONIC comic sequences.  definitely worth checking out.

At this point, it's difficult to tell the completely-serious-ridiculousness of the 90s from actual satire. Released in 2001, Max Payne exists in a time so close to the height of 90s bravado that it hasn't quite dissipated yet, but we might finally be ready to start talking about how silly it all was. For a fifteen-year-old Playstation port, the game itself has held up surprisingly well, perhaps even gaining a bit more accessibility in the move to the PC. The interface is clean and intuitive, the transition between shooting gobs of interchangeable mooks and the fastforwardable/rewindable cutscenes is smooth, and the bullet time mechanic is game-changingly useful without entirely dominating play. Other than the platforming elements - that have no business in this game in the first place - Max Payne is still a joy to play. Even when being encouraged to abuse the quick save function to solve cheap instant-death scenarios, it doesn't stop being fun. But what makes the game memorable are the little touches: the casual nature of the conversations between enemies before you burst into a room, the sensible placement of guns and painkillers, the way Max looks towards and mentions cutscene-inducing items but lets the player activate them on his or her timescale. Where Max Payne shows its age is in the flat, pasted on faces of its character models. Everyone is made out of sharp-edged boxes and Max himself is caught in a perpetual squint that never fails to decimate his dramatic creditability. This weakness only highlights the brilliance of the graphic novel styled cutscenes though, as they can be relied upon for any moment that wants to hold on to its pathos. And that's what Max Payne is made of: a handful of brilliant choices that leave its equal amount of flaws mostly ignorable.

Very great game, if you havent played it already your missing out big time. Great story, gritty atmosphere, excellent gunplay, and last but certainly not least the bullet time. This game would have still been a great game with out it but it makes the game so much better.

Probably one of my favorite games ever.  Max Payne bleeds noir and is oozing with style, like a cross between a John Woo and Quentin Tarantino movie.  The story is pretty standard ho hum stuff, but the way it is delivered is phenomenal.  The comic strip cutscenes are particularly nice since they still look good more than a decade after the game has become graphically outdated.  Payne's narration is great stuff; describing the world and ongoings around him with a surrealistic, morose style in typical noir fashion.

There are a few problems though.  For one, if you have Windows 7 or beyond you'll have trouble getting the game to run.  You'll need a community made sound patch for the cutscenes and you'll need to be sure to run this game in compatibility mode, otherwise it won't work.

Technical issues aside, Max Payne is a really hard game, but that difficulty is often unfair and it can be a source of frequent frustration.  The enemies don't have realistic reactions and will literally snap towards you the milisecond you appear in their general vicinity, shooting at you with pin point accuracy to the point where a guy with a sawed off shotgun will snipe you from across the room.

You'll find a lot of guns becoming useless for you while the enemy still often uses them to great effect, which is a real bummer.  The signature dual berretas become really useless really really fast, and the shotgun becomes equally useless later on since you cannot blow anyone off their feet not even in melee range, and they'll gun you down while you get a second shot in since they barely recoil to a shotgun blast to the face.

Familiarize yourself with quick save/quick load and try to strategize your approach to difficult encounters with bullet time, but really, Max Payne puts it best; It wasn't about how smart or how good you were. It was chaos and luck
