reviewText:
I completed Max Payne a couple of days ago. It was a really fantastic experience from the beginning to the end!

Just over a decade ago a friend gave it to me as a gift on Retail CD for PC. I played it for a bit but never had a chance to complete it back then. Unfortunately the CD stopped being recognized and I gave up on it. But coincidentally 4 years ago I was gifted on Steam by another friend.

This time I decided to play it again. I never had any issues running the game on my Windows 7 system. The only issue I had was the sound being messed up. There was no sound in some parts of the game and other sounds disappeared. It is a compatibility issue with the latest operating systems. But luckily this problem was easily fixed by a Max Payne: Sound Fix! patch that is found in the Steam Community Hub Guides tab. After that the game ran flawlessly!

Anyway, the graphics aren't up to par with the latest computer technologies, but they are of a high standard and exceptional for its time. The story is compelling, if sometimes a little difficult to follow, and once you start playing it, you don't want to stop! You want to know what's around the next corner and where the story will turn next, it really does get you hooked!

Level designs are varied and the gameplay is not repetitive. There are a total of 25 chapters in the game and each and every one of them is different so it constantly keeps you engaged. You can also manually save and not rely on checkpoint savings like some of the older PC titles. This is particularly important for a game like Max Payne where you'll come across difficult enemies. Enemies range from street thugs to military commandos. The first few stages of the game will present little problems for players, as enemies will rarely engage you and create life threatening situations. The latter stages of the game present much more complex situations, bombarding you with enemies in very close quarter areas. Enemies are pretty relentless throughout the game, so it's wise to sniff out painkillers and keep plenty in stock to top up any lost health and to also make sure to manually save each time you overcome difficult enemies or scenarios!

You also have a variety of weapons to choose from. Whether a baseball bat, handguns, assault rifles, grenade launchers, snipers, etc. You have full control over the enemies. Not to mention that in every particular scenario of the game you'll find that you'll need to choose different weapons for different situations! You cannot rely solely on one weapon only, that's what I like about this game. In one situation you'll need to throw grenades and in another you'll be requiring to use the sniper to kill enemies that are shooting from far above you.

Max Payne is also the first game to introduce bullet-time effects (like those seen in the Matrix). During a gun fight Max can slow down everything around him to allow him better aim and an edge over his enemies. You could instigate the bullet-time parts of the game over and over again and they would still be as awesome to watch as the first time.

It's just great fun to let loose with any weapon and reap the benefits of destruction. Not everything is about killing, as some moments will call upon Max to solve mini puzzles, or even traverse hazardous routes in order to progress.

Overall Max Payne is a fantastic third-person shooter, full of action and energy. The story is dark and backed by immersive film noir attributes. The graphics depict New York City in a stark fashion. The gameplay is highly entertaining and a complete bullet-fest from start to finish!

I have not had this much fun with a game in a long time. Pure storytelling, gunplay bliss. If you can overlook the graphics, and despite my only limited hours playing so far, have been awesome. Challenging, surprisingly tactical, and again, fantastic gameplay.
good once you fix it up

Remedy's first Woo/Matrix inspired, action packed, third-person shooter in the Payne franchise delivers on what you might expect yet is somewhat limited in scope compared to their future efforts. People might remember the Max Payne games as a moody homage to noire detective thrillers, interrupted by bouts of exaggerated slow motion action but the reality on both accounts is surprisingly different.

The story (although creatively executed through comic book panels, expressive art, and some iconic musical themes) couldn't be more generic but that's OK because of the unique tone that remedy has struck and are now somewhat known for. From the outset it may look like a dire tale of a cop whom's family is murdered, framed for the death of a fellow DEA agent and on the run through an abandoned New York City (by way of that good old excuse, a dire blizzard) killing his way up a chain of endless wacky criminals and mob families to eventually discover a deeper conspiracy. Max Payne is remembered in part for its great story but the writing and structure themselves aren't particularly well executed, with far too many criminals, conspiracies, and betrayals for even Max's gravely narration to keep track of, and a fractured narrative structure that serves to confuse rather than contextualise the events of the story. Apart from some major Wikipedia plot points, if you asked me to tell you what happened in the first Max Payne I would draw a blank. The inherent character and tone that Remedy bring are what makes the story engaging. It manages to both take itself seriously and be incredibly self knowing, occasionally fourth wall breaking, and treading into pastiche territory upon occasion. There are some very funny in-game TV show's to watch and NPC conversions to overhear which break the tension of the story and combat, and give what is essentially an endless series of rooms to shoot though a sense of place within a larger world. The flavour of the story and the slow motion shooting mechanics and are't just the core of the experience, they are the experience.

Despite the bevy of weapons (including duel pistols, shotguns, Uzi's, rifles, and some more ridiculous ♥♥♥♥ later on!) the gameplay loop consists of shooting your way through endless empty subway stations, hotels, office complexes, and gang hideouts, slow-mo launching yourself into a room filled with enemies while clumsily contorting your body into odd poses as you attempt to leverage your limited time to exert the maximum amount of payne. It's clumsy and unrefined but undeniably fun. A modern interpretation would feature better animations for jumping over cover and other contextual actions but this is mainly of visual importance. Only some occasional unintuitive environmental puzzle design hinders your endless slaughter.

The way the game is balanced is somewhat of a double edged sword. It's quite difficult and unforgiving (Max will perish in a few shots without downing a few dozen handfuls of delicious painkillers) to incentivize accuracy, the use of the slow-motion mechanic, and to make fights feel satisfying. The downside is that it prevented me from getting too creative with the tools they had given me. I ended up sticking to particular lines of sight and repeating consistently successful moves whilst fantasising about slow-mo launching myself down a spiral staircase or letting lose on dozens of enemies in the open, but I guess there are always cheats for that sort of thing. The levels are designed as a series of rooms with limited scripted events, it's all very simple (with only unlock-able difficulties and time trial modes offering replay value) and as such, can become repetitive although new weapons and drips of narrative context motivated me to continue despite this.

The first Payne outing is about establishing a tone and a gameplay rhythm that would later be refined upon as well as showing off some impressive graphical fidelity (if you can ignore Muppet hands and Max's permanently constipated facial expression) and slow motion technological accomplishments that were impressive for the time and still hold up today. Max Payne 2 is the superior game in every way, making the first seem like more of a proof of concept or a tech demo with a smaller scope by comparison, but all the ingredients are here and they still make for a fun game.
10/10 best game ever. Too bad it doesn't run perfectly on win7.
Amazing story and good gameplay.
Absolute classic. Of course the graphics looks obsolete today, but the gun play is still amazing and noir story stands firmly on the legs of weathered NY detective bent on revenge.

Fantastic game, though this port has terrible sound issues, but from what I understand there are sound patches you can download. Still, I missed out on most audible dialogue, and that hindered my experience. Apart from sound issues, this game is amazing.

max payne (1) is one of those games that you won't really get the appeal unless you play it, and in many ways you could claim it's a niche game... it juxtaposes the 'mindless shooter' gameplay elements with a very deeply developed story that could easily be ignored if you just want to shoot things and jump around. however, if you let yourself get sucked into the story, it borders on a psychological horror mixed with a few cliche 'good guy turned anti-hero searching for total revenge' story elements. the best part is, although it's a very serious and dark game, the game does not one bit take itself seriously. there is enough tongue-in-cheek humor to last a lifetime, and at times, the game will even mock itself. max payne is definitely one of the best action shooters ever made, even though it's a bit dated nowadays. i would recommend it if you're looking for an older style of gameplay with a few tweaks and perks that can't be found in most, or if you want a high-octane game with a deep, gritty storyline. it's definitely a game i am glad i decidd to give a chance years ago despite it not being one i'd usually care to try. also if you like it, max payne 2 is everything awesome about the first game made tenfold. this game will always hold a large part of my heart.\nEDIT:\nsteam holiday sale has both 1 and 2 for 2.99 and if you have any doubts about this game you have no excuse (unless you're broke) not to try it now. get this game, it's amazing.

One of the definers of modern 3rd person shooters. The beggining is a little slow but after you get inside Max's head and start seeing the story and everything through his eyes, it becomes a tense experience, with an overwhelmingly satisfactory ending. A must play for everyone!

reviewText: Max Payne is a very interesting game. It looks like it was made on a budget of 10 $5 footlongs and a cheap toaster. Max has a permanent constipated look on his face, the textures are really low-res, and the voice acting is sub-par. Those things though are part of what makes this such a charming game. Max's metaphors and similies are like poetry, and the game plays like a dream. The story is gripping, I had no problems getting through it, which I credit to the way it's delivered. The game's cutscenes are almost all in a graphic novel format. You get 4-5 pages of 2 - 3 panels each at the start and end of each segment, 6 - 7 pages of 2 - 3 panels at the end of each chapter, and 1 - 2 pages during gameplay. The shortness of these cutscenes means you're out of them and back in the game in a heartbeat, ready to shoot more mooks in slow motion. Max Payne plays very much like an arcade shooter, with short, frequent encounters and occasional bosses. It's only downfall in my eyes are the dream sequences at the start of each chapter. This is not a platforming game at all, so there's no reason for me to be walking narrow pathways over insta-death pits except padding. Luckily, there are only two of them, and the second one breaks the fourth wall in an amusing way.\n\ntl;dr, buy Max Payne. It's a great value at any price, and a very memorable game.

reviewText:
Max Payne is one of those games I never got to play back when it was originally released and by the time I got around to getting a copy technology had advanced to the point where my computer refused to play so it took so long for me to actually get to the point where I had both a working copy and the interest in playing it had become an extremely dated game.

However, even nowadays, with compatibility fixes and all, the game still doesn't play right, the mouse movement isn't as smooth as one would want it an FPS game and the textures and movement is very jagged.

Maybe someday I will find myself replaying this on a 10 year old PC and enjoying it but today ain't that day. It is not a game I can judge by the standards of when it was released because I didn't play it back then and by today's standards it's a dated game with many other better alternatives available

reviewText:
i found out how to fix this game and make it work for windows 7 how to below

I had this problem and searched far and wide for a fix. What did it for me was to go to my 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Max Payne' folder, right click 'maxpayne.exe', go to the Compatibility tab at the top of the new dialog box, check 'Run this program in compatibility mode for:' and select 'Windows 98 / Windows Me'. I also selected 'Run this program as an administrator', but I think compatibility mode has to be set first.

tldr; set compatibility mode for maxpayne.exe in the max payne directory to Windows 98/Windows ME + run as administrator.

This was for Max Payne 1, but I'm guessing the same could apply for Max Payne 2.

reviewText:
Horrible film and infamously bad player model aside, one of the best pre-Resident Evil 4 third person shooters. 8/10

+Who knew that John Woo and film noir mixed so perfectly?
+Surprisingly well written story
+Great vocal performance by James Mccafrey
+Those dream sequences!
+Plenty of classic noir references, and some odd nods to Norse and Greek mythology
+The gameplay isn't quite like any other third person shooter, it has a fast paced, run and gun style; almost like a third person Quake or Unreal
+The Slo-Mo, while kind of a gimmick, is still fun to use.
+The final level is glorious. It is the very definition of a climax.

+/- It is fiendishly difficult, there are some sequences that completely rely on trial and error. You will have to mash that quicksave button.

-The villain isn't really fleshed out that well (she is only introduced around an hour in)
-I would have liked to have seen more of Vladmeer and Mona.
-I mentioned the quicksave, well that is because there is not really any type of autosaving, or checkpoints. If you die, and forget to save frequently, you have to restart the entire level.
-The secondary voice actors are pretty meh. The repeated sound clips of enemies yelling IT'S PAYNE!" or "PAYNE?!" get annoying quickly
-(now for nitpicks) Max's infamous in game face. The game's writer
recommended: is quite talented... As a writer
hoursPlayed: not a model. He did not need to devote his likeness for the player model. It looks kind of... rough.\n-Those .5 seconds when you can't shoot after diving."

reviewText:
This review is for the game ''Max Payne'',a third-person shooter video game
,developed by the video game company Remedy Entertainment.
The game was published by Gathering of Developers
(now known as Gathering,a daughter company of Take-Two Interactive) in North America
and 3D Realms in Europe on July 2001 for Microsoft Windows.
and released in Semptember 22 on 2006(in Europe).
The game can be run through Microsoft Windows,Playstation 2,Xbox,Game Boy Advance,Mac OS,iOS & Android.
The game uses the MAX-FX 1.0.
Genre(s):Third-person shooter
Mode(s):Single-player
Distribution:CD-ROM,DVD,cartridge,digital download.

Plot
The game takes place in New York city,in December 2001,where you take control of a former NYPD officer and a renegade DEA (Drug Enforcement Administration),Max Payne,who's being arrested by the police at the top of a skyscraper.
While he is being arrested he experiences a flashback which explains his life story and why he is being chased.

On August 22. 1998 NYPD detective,Max payne,just finishing his work goes home only to find his wife and his newborn daughter,Rose,brutally murdered.Max kills the junkies responsible for the murder of his loved ones but he is too late.After that incident he transfers to DEA in order to find out who is responsible and ultimately take revenge.

The game's content majority takes place during the last two days while Max is operating inside the Punchinello Mafia family,under the Don Angelo Punchinello(family's head),responsible for the trafficking of the Valkyr drug.After given a message to meet Alex(his Dea contact and Max's best friend) Max find Alex on the NYC Rosco Subway Station.His arrival at the Station results in encountering Jack's Lupino mobster group(Punchinello's crime family underboss)who were attempting an armed robbery.There he will come in contact with Aesir Corporation(just company bonds),a mysterious New York corporation,who is bound to play an important role on the story later on.

Later on Max Payne will come in contact with Alex who informs him that Max has been exposed by a mole in the Punchinello family.Seconds later Alex gets killed by a possible Killer Suit(Aesir's corporation hitmen).To make things worse Payne becomes suspect because of the fact that he is still an undercover,therefore an enemy,and is now chased by both the Punchinello crime family and also by the Deputy Chief Jim Bravura.


Succeding the Station's events he goes to a Lupino's motel where he finds and kills the Finito Brothers(Vinnie's Gognitti subordinate).After that Max travels in one of Lupino's bars,finds the diary of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥,Candy,and the fact that he sends video tapes of her and a mysterious <<one-eyed Alfred>>(an important figure later on).Eventually Max finds and kills Rico Muerte(a former hitman working for Punchinello) and Candy.In the bar Max found the location of Gognitti.

After chasing Gognitti from his apartment through the city and the subway,Max learns about a nightclub named Ragna Rok.There Max spares Gognitti and Max proceeds in killing the so called ''antichrist'' Lupino.After killing him and his men he encounters Mona Sax,Lisa's Punchinello twin sister and contract killer,who sedates Max by throwing something in his drink,telling him that she wants to kill the Don too.

After a dream about his family's death he wakes up and manages to escape the Mafia base and after that he finds himself in the bar where he earlier killed Rico Muerte.There Max finds Frank The Bat" Niagara who had captured Max and was going to kill him.After these events Max is approached by Vladimir Lem(Russian's mafia leader and Punichinello's prime enemy) and is proposed a brief alliance.With Vlad's help Max seizes the cargo ship Charon and kills Boris Dime
recommended: and arranges a meeting in Don's restaurant
hoursPlayed: only to bee a set up resulting in the bombing of the place and the killing of the rest of Punchinello's men(by Max Payne of course).\n\nMax Payne
helpfulPercent: heads for Punchinello's residence only to find and kill the Trio(Vince Mugnaio
votesHelpful: \nPilate Providence (AKA "Big Brother")
votesTotal: and Joe "Deadpan" Salem) Don's most feared hitman group.Max later finds the corpse of the Don's wife(Mona's twin sister) and discovers that the Don is just a pawn for the Aesir Corporation.The Don is killed by the agents of Nicole Horne
votesFunny: the Ceo
commentsCount: and Payne is being injected an overose of the Valkyr drug.Payne then suffers nightmares about his family but manages to survive the dosage.\n\nThe game now takes it's final course.Max finds out and underground military research complex where inside that complex Valkyr is being researched
column16: an experiment that attempted to improve but failed to do so the stamina and morale of the U.S soldiers.The drug research was halted but Horne
column17: who was the leading expert of the so called Valhalla Project
column18: after becoming the Ceo she restarted the research and used the company as a front for producing the Valkyr.Max escapes the complex after a successful destruction by the Aesir Corporation in order to destroy the evidence.\n\nLater on Max encounters B.B who admits that was bribed by Nicole Horne to kill Max and Alex.Max then chases the traitor B.B Hensley(Payne's other DEA contact) and kills him.After doing so Max gets a phone call from Alfred Wooden(''one-eyed Alfred'')
column19: asking him to come to Asgard Building.There he learns that Alfred is a part of the Inner Circle
column20: a powerful society with strong ties to the U.S government.The Inner Circle want to stop Nicole Horne but they can't because of\nthe fact that Alfred was being blackmailed by the Punchinello family over the tapes coming from the Lupino's pimp club.They ask Max to kill Horne in exchange for dropping the charges against him.Suddenly
column21: Aesir assassins invade the building and kill everyone except Max
column22: who manages to run away
column24: who pretends to have died.\n\nIn the end Max arrives at the Aesir Corporation building
column25: kills the guards and at the top of the building confronts Nicole Horne who boards a helicopter.Max shoots wires that holds the buildin's antenna
column26: which breaks off and crashes onto the helicopter
column27: successfully killing Horne.While these events Mona Sax dies from a shot in the head but her body vanishes unknowningly.\n\nIn the end Max
column28: as said in Plot's section first paragraph
column29: gets arrested by the policemen.Max has finally taken his revenge for the death of his loved ones.Max smiles satisfied while knowing that Woden will get the charges dropped and Woden smiles as well
column30:
satisfied that Horne has been stopped.

Gameplay-Themes
Max Payne is a third-person shooter with neo-noir elements.You can use many weapons(9mm pistol
column33: sniper rifle etc.).Unfortunatelly you can't use any means of transportation in the entire game.There's a useful thing you can do called Bullet-Time that you can use in order to slow time and dodge or fire at your enemy.\n\nAs for the themes the game's elements are named from figures and mythsfrom Norse mythology(Valkyr
column39:
Balder etc.).

Recap
I find this game an absolute work of art.The story
column43:
the gameplay everything to be absolutely breath-taking and mind blowing.It has a little audio problems but can be solved in a matter of minutes.

I definitely recommend this game.Don't be fooled by the fact that it's a 2001 game.Can easily compete in fun with modern 2013-14 games in my opinion.

Thank you Remedy Entertainment and Rockstar Games for this wonderful game.

P.S Max Payne has only started his journey through the night.The pain has only just begun.More will follow."

After a dream about his family's death he wakes up and manages to escape the Mafia base and after that he finds himself in the bar where he earlier killed Rico Muerte.There Max finds Frank The Bat" Niagara who had captured Max and was going to kill him.After these events Max is approached by Vladimir Lem(Russian's mafia leader and Punichinello's prime enemy) and is proposed a brief alliance.With Vlad's help Max seizes the cargo ship Charon and kills Boris Dime

reviewText:
Luego de incontables idas y vueltas, logre hacerlo funcionar, y al finalizarlo solo me quedo una duda: realmente valio la pena?

Max Payne nos situa en la piel de un policia que lo ha perdido todo, su mente despojada de pensamiento alguno excepto la venganza, y es alli donde comienza una de las cacerias mas populares de los ultimos tiempos, una guerra de un solo hombre como solamente Max puede ocasionar.

No hay mucho mas que decir, puesto que la historia es, sin mas ni menos, realmente confusa, con nombres apareciendo ocasionalmente con el objetivo de ganar complejidad, pero sin darse cuenta de que se comprometio la simpleza original con la que nos veiamos enganchados: la muerte de nuestra familia.

Sin embargo, no se puede negar la espectacularidad de las escenas de accion, que gozan de un notable efecto de bullet time"
recommended: si bien muchos juegos la utilizan hoy en dia
voteText: y esa dote de grandeza es innegable
helpfulPercent: constituyendo asi la casi unica ventaja de este titulo.\n\nLa repetitividad y las frases empalagosas abundan por doquier
votesHelpful: relegando a esta aventura a un segundo plano en la actualidad
votesTotal: necesitando asi de unas buenas injecciones de nostalgia para poder ser disfrutado\n\nValoracion final: "Una entretenida entrega de disparos
votesFunny: que se ve perjudicada por su ambiciosa historia y poca variedad de situaciones"\n\nNota: 7/10"

reviewText: Max Payne is a game without a lot of the advancements" made in the 3rd person shooter genre. The game features open yet often small levels
date: with very little cover or areas to hide behind. The game will often kill you suddenly and without warning
recommended: with enemies showing up out of nowhere and many blind entrances through doors walking you right into death with enemies already pointing guns at the door. And there is little to no checkpointing
hoursPlayed: with the player having to make their own with quicksaves
voteText: which they'll definitely need because as I mentioned the game will kill you suddenly and without mercy regularly.\n\nThe gameplay consists of utilizing the bullet time and dodge mechanics to outmanuver bullets
helpfulPercent: shoot more precisely and deal more damage in a short period of time to kill enemies before they kill you. The game has no cover mechanics and attempting to pick off enemies from behind cover rarely works. If you stand still in a fight
votesHelpful: you will likely die. You must abuse horizontal movement and bullet time to your advantage to keep the enemy from getting a bead on you
votesTotal: because shots are often lethal.\n\nDuring my first playthrough
votesFunny: I was frequently frustrated by the game. When I reconsidered the trial and error battles as puzzles I enjoyed myself much more. Every abrupt and sudden death which was previously unfair suddenly became elaborate puzzles I had to solve using bullet time and focus firing priority targets. By the time I reached the end of the game I realized some techniques relating to the bullet time mechanic I could use to play more efficiently and immediately played it again on the next difficulty. The second playthrough was even more fun as things were more challenging but I felt like I had only just grasped the bullet time mechanics and was making full use of it at last. When I had finished the second run I was contemplating what I could do to play better for the next difficulty. Very few games new or old compel me to do that
commentsCount:
and it was that hard "unfairness" that made me want to come back.

The game's plot is enjoyably campy. It's the kind of sincere corniness that games had before they tried too hard at being quirky and random. It's enjoyable and skippable which makes it easier to replay the game without playing through interactive cutscenes.

Buy Max Payne if you like arcade-like 3rd person action games and trial and error difficulty."

reviewText:
MAX PAYNE, a rock star title. thats a good start already.

Pros:
>Excellent Voice acting
>Good Story
>Simple but fun gameplay (the slow motion ability is awsome *_*)- good selection of weapons too.
>Challenging Game Modes (All variations of the story mode but with things like time limit etc.)

Cons:
>Some would say the graphics are dated but i still enjoyed it. Especially the model faces, hahaha.
>From reading the forums the game might have an audio issue on windows 7 and 8 but fixes can found in the guide section.

Overall just a really fun game to play with an interesting story. Blast your way through the bad guys!!!!

6/10

reviewText:
! WARNING !

This game suffers from severe issues on newer systems that prevent it from launching and if you manage to start it via workarounds (bat file to force the game to use only single core), most of the in game audio is missing (though that can supposedly be fixed with an non-official sound patch that lurks somewhere in the depths of the internet), making the game a colossal pain to sort out before it'll run in satisfactory manner and as such, cannot in good conscience recommend this game to anyone in it's current state.

*****

Behind the issues hides a very solid third person action thriller, with old school gameplay and quality voice acting, a story about a New York detective trying to avenge the murder of his family.

Game itself can be clunky and the graphics/character models campy, but as said, past all that is a game well worth playing!

reviewText: So basicly Max Payne, a cop in the NYPD, returns home one day to find his wife and baby daughter murdered at the hands of drug addicts, high on a designer drug called Valkyr. After 3 years of working on the case, Max and his best friend Alex go undercover to bust a V-deal. However, things go wrong: Alex is suddenly killed, and Max is framed for his murder. Hunted by the cops and driven by determination to avenge his family, Max Payne sets out to uncover the truths behind his family's murder.

reviewText:
A game that marked my first years as a gamer. Definately recommending it. Epic dark themed story, full of sarcastic jokes of a cop that was in the bad place at a bad time, with his family paying the consequences. Now he has dedicated his life to seek the true responsibles for the loss of his loved beings. Secret government departments, greed and power addicted villians AND BULLET TIME!!!! Awesome game mechanics and the introduction (in its time) of this one (bullet time) in particular. Even though the graphics seem (and are indeed) old, everything else compensates it. If you are reading this DON'T MISS IT!!

Afraid of the compatibility issues?? NO PROBLEM. I was afraid too when I tried my luck and bought it here praying for it to work with the simple steps I read about. In the Max Payne directory of steam: Right click to maxpayne.exe, properties, compatibility tab, select compatibility mode Windows 98/ME and Run as Administrator = MAGIC.

-Sound problems? There's an easy fix online and it's a major thread (resolved) topic on the community hub of this game. Google the fix or just click on the link given in the forums, WORKS LIKE A CHARM.

-People saying NOT WORKING ON MULTICORE PROCESSORS" and "NOT COMPATIBLE WITH AMD VIDEO CARDS" or "NOT WORKING ON x64 OS SYSTEMS" HAHA NICE TRY!! I'm running it on Windows 7 Ultimate x64
date: Core 2 Quad 2.83 GHZ and an AMD HD5770 so :P DO NOT MISS THIS MASTERPIECE.\n\nAs an extra
recommended: there are a lot of GOD-BLESSED AWESOME mods out there. I almost cried when I tried the Kung-Fu mod... its a MUST have
hoursPlayed: replay value  x 100000. I hope this helped you decide buying this awesome game. DO IT. WHY ARE YOU STILL READING THIS???? BUY IT."

reviewText:
If you're going to read this, then focus. Put a couple of minutes aside. Pay full attention to me, because this isn't just a review. I'm going to pour my heart into this because I feel that's what this game deserves. This isn't just something you can score.

At first, this game's story is exactly like your standard anime, but it very quickly becomes something far greater. In my 32 hour campaign, there wasn't a single second in which I wasn't enjoying the absolute hell out of everything the game had to offer me. The adorable characters, the amazing story, the graphics of all of the spells...there wasn't a single second where I wasn't entertained.

It got to the point where once I reached the end of the game, I wasn't crying just because of the way the story ended, but also because of the very fact that the game is over now. Sure I knew I could do a new game plus, but something about finishing the game was just so heart wrenching. I can't even remember the last time I shed a tear, and I am a rather stoic man, so it symbolizes a lot that this amazingly emotional game managed to make me cry in different ways at the same time.

Somehow, the repetitive combat isn't a bad thing. The spell effects of each and every spell are entertaining and beautiful enough to keep you interested in seeing them forever. Getting experience and skill points is fun no matter what, to the point where even the slightly-mandatory grinding is even fun. That's saying so much.

Perhaps the most touching, is that it's a fully realized PC port. A game built with a JRPG engine has full mouse and keyboard support. Sure it seems like it would be standard for PC ports to have such things, but seeing a lack of mouse control in recent PC ports like DMC: Special Edition, it's hard not to feel grateful that the developers worked so hard to make mouse and keyboard work everywhere in this game. The amount of love they must have for this game must rival mine. And it does not surprise me, because it's extremely easy to fall in love with this game. You will have to practice the keyboard controls a bit (it took me a little bit to find out that Page Up and Page Down helps you aim your spells in combat, and Page Up re-centers your camera when exploring dungeons) but it won't take long, and the game's turn-based nature is very conducive with this control scheme, ensuring you have as much time as you need to figure out how, and where, to aim your spells. Give it a while, and you won't notice any difference in speed from casting a spell at the right position using a keyboard or a controller.

And to top it all off; my girlfriend gifted me this game and all of its dlc's. Even if it wasn't such an amazing game, it would be worth appreciating simply because she got it for me. But it turned out to be my personal game of the year. Deandra, I love you, and I can't thank you enough for giving me this art, and I can't thank Compile Heart and Idea Factory enough for creating it.

reviewText:
Personal rating: 10/10
Replayability: Low
Budget: Worth it.
Lenght: A few days.

WARNING: Do not play any of the later games first. This title will become unplayable after trying the more improved mechanics of the sequels.

Max Payne is a truly noire story with a very iconic dark and gritty narative of the classic hard-boiled city detective, who goes through trauma on a daily basis while half-drunk and shot up on pills. While there is absoloutely nothing funny about Max Payne's story, it's of couse a bit of a parody on the noire genre.

As a third-person shooter, the game employes bullet-time, basically matrix-like dodging maneuvers and is generally just very well made. The soundtrack and the story are both excellent also.

reviewText: This game is a gritty third-person shooter about a police officer called Max Payne. The game has bullet time elements which allow Max to pull of incredible kills and survive against the odds. The game starts with the murder of your wife and child, and doesn't ever get any happier, even at the end. The gameplay is decent but nothing too amazing due to it's age. The game is interesting, exiting, and fun as well as very engaging too. Though at points the grittiness of the game make it a bit horrible to look at, it was an artistic decision. The game has comic book style cutscenes which are nice to look at and read through and carry the story along brilliantly and much better than a normal cutscene" would have been able to at the time of the game's release. The game is stands up to this date and you must play through it if you want to play the sequels as it allows you to not only see but feel the pain Max has been through to get where he is in the sequels. The AI in this game are difficult even though you start it on the easiest setting
date: but the quick save feature allows you to get round this difficulty with ease. The sound on the game isn't perfect but is bearable. It's level design is very good and allows exploring for any extra supplies such as guns
hoursPlayed:
and pain killers if needed. The character of Max Payne and the story of his life full of pain and suffering are both brilliant and a real experience to go through. The graphics in this game are certainly impressive for the time of release and are no issue at all.
The game can be difficult at times and there are more engaging games out there that can keep you playing for longer sessions at a time but this game is overall pretty decent.

9/15 - "Fairly decent gritty third-person shooter about pain and suffering""

reviewText:
Broken

The reason I am giving this game a bad review is NOT because it is a bad game. It's pretty much unanimous that this game is a great one. The issue is that if you have Windows 7 IT WILL (most likely) NOT WORK. Neither will Max Payne 2 for that matter. If you look at the compatability it even says that it will only work on XP. I bought the bundle and was sorely disappointed to find out that I couldn't even run either of them in compatability mode.

Now that I have said that, some people have been able to run these games no problem in compatability mode and there are a myriad of fixes you can try if that fails. The reason I am not recommending this game is because I spent an entire day trying to get these games to work somehow and tried all if not most of those fixes and nothing worked and now these games are just sitting in my library and I just sigh in sadness and regret whenever I see them.

I mean you can buy it and who knows? Maybe you can get it to work? It's really just a gamble to buy this game. In my opinion it is not worth the headache and you're better off emulating it somehow or buying it for your PS2. Unless of course you have Windows XP, in which case go for it! I just wish someone had warned me that this game is so hard to run on Windows 7 and that's why I made this review, hopefully it will help you guys.

reviewText:
If you're using any operating system after Windows XP, I wouldn't buy this game.
This game is praised for being a great game.
However, it's getting to the actual game itself that is the problem.

Firstly, Max Payne runs, but will not show up. Checking your task manager indicates that there is a process running, but there is no actual game showing.

Secondly, there is no sound in cut scenes and most of the game.

Both do have fixes, but were done by players and the community.
The company couldn't care less about this game. These issues have been around since Vista came out, which means about 2004-5. However, there has been nothing suggested and no fixes made by the company.

reviewText:
My review can simply be summed up as 'Thumbs down with the Steam Version' 'Thumbs up to the game design itself'.

As noted by many in the Steam forums. The Steam version has sound compatibility issues and there is no sound to either cut scenes or background music, even though the sound works with everything else for example bullet fire and npc dialogues. So why the developers continue to argue for $10.00 when this product is faulty on Steam is a criminal payne. The developers can be found here http://remedygames.com/

I'm not sure why this was nominated as a game with one of the best stories. Its definitely a long stretch from that with its over the top corny pictures and cheap budget voice acting, however the game is definitely fun as a fps which harbors a unique cinematic matrix trick at your characters disposal.

Made back in 2001 the graphics are somewhat dated, but the game is still entertaining and will give you a similar adventure feeling comparable to that of Half Life. It's the clever level designs and the many secret places and passages that they hide that make it a delight to explore. Personally I recommend the youtube walkthrough by countduncan if you want to find many of the secrets. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3cSywp2PAPGempVYWo9CioXBQnRVWVDS

The game has 4 modes, easy, medium, hard and a time mode. Even easy is really difficult in comparison to some of the games of today and thanks to the F5 quick save at your disposal you will be practically using it after every gun shot. The time mode is just a get out of my way, mow everything down while you sprint, brandishing two uzi's or an automatic shotty. However even this is really, really, really tricky also.

So what is the story? The story involves Max Payne who 3 years ago arrived home to find his wife and child murdered by 3 addicts hyped up on a new drug called 'V'. After the funeral he takes up the offer of an old friend Alex Balder and leaves NYPD to work with the DEA and try and get this new drug off the streets. Working covertly undercover, Max Payne is set up as an operative inside the Punchinello crime family after they get a serious lead pointing their attention to an underboss known as Jack Lupino transporting the drug. This operation is so tight lipped that only Max's true identity is only known by 2 people, that is Alex Balder and B.B who is also an administrative DEA.

B.B eventually gets a tip that something BIG is going down at Roscoe Street Subway station and informs both Max and Alex to get down there and investigate. Little do they know it's a trap which exposes Max Paynes true identity to the Punchinello family. Max knowing there is no where to hide and that a hit has now been placed on his head, decides to go all Humphrey Bogart and hunt down the Don of this family himself. On his journey he will meet a variety of colorful under-bosses and assassins which he will need to take out of the equation and cater for first.

Eventually he learns more about this V drug how it was originally designed and tested by the government to try and enhance the performance and morale of soldiers during the gulf war. However the project was quickly halted in 1995 when the test results showed damning mental side effects. Problem was certain high ranking officials saw potential in this drug and decided to keep testing and manufacturing it in secret. Not long after that Max learns what connection the 3 addicts had to do with his wife and why she needed to die. Armed with the new revelation of what really happened and slightly influenced with the invigorating power of V on himself he tracks down all those responsible and kills them.

I guess in a nutshell because the story has some aspects similar to the well known and publicized MKUltra experiments the CIA performed unknowingly on many of the public, it often gets nominated as a 'great story', but seriously nothing still quite beats the original...
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_MKUltra

Since the Steam version is completely broken you may want to download a completely working sound version for yourself here...

mediafire/download/oa8aeji5j70lh8z/Max+Payne++1+No+Sound+Fix.exe (just put www. before mediafire and .com after media fire)

Just create a steamapps folder named Max Payne and install it in that and then run exe direct or add it to your steam account. It's a fun piece of gaming art.

reviewText:
Bruhhhhhh, let me tell you about this game. I played the 3rd one before deciding to buy the other 2 so I could figure out what this alcoholic was narrating about.

Now the first game in this series is good, I enjoyed it, even though the game is about 15 years old. I get through some of the parts in Chapter 1, and I get to Part 7. Now stuff escalates pretty fast through this game, with 2 dudes coming at you with dual Ingrams and stuff. So I'm chasing this sad sap on the rooftops and he goes to jump. The game cuts to a cutscene where the guy is supposed to make the jump, but for me, he misses the ledge and falls down. I know this is a glitch because when I go to that ledge, he is just literally standing there, facing the frickin wall, acting like nothing frickin happened. So I figure the guy will just reset when the game cuts to the next cutscene, but no. The game progresses until it gets to this certain cutscene where the guy is supposed to activate something but he's NOT FRICKIN THERE.

So, I give up on this game. I've tried about 4 times but the same thing happens. It probably has supposed to do with Windows 10, but hey, whatever.

So if you run Windows 10 and like advancing through game's that eventually glitch and break, this game is surely up your ally.

IGN gave this a 9.3, and said If this is what Payne feels like
date: then I'm a self-proclaimed masochist." If they were at my house and watched me while I played this

Not a fan of this game.

reviewText:
Summary : Rockstar should not sell a product with common compatibility issues with no warning while charging 10.00$

Be warned, your audio may not work in cutscenes and in-game dialogue.

When I purchased Max Payne a while ago, I was expecting the full experience, but when I launched it, the dialogue was extremely glitchy and I didn't have any audio in cutscenes.

I looked on the forums and found users with simular issues and a post from an ex-developer whom had a way to fix the game and get audio to work.

It required a quick fix installation by an awesome modder, who fixed the compatibility issues himself, along with listing a treasure trove of mods. Why is this topic not stickied? Why is this fix not installed on Max Payne in the first place?

Rockstar should of aready patched / edited the game to make it fully compatible with Windows 7 and 8. Bringing up an old title on steam, while charging a moderate price of 10.00$, I expect a certain ammount of effort in making the game workable. I see NO EXCUSE if your charging money.

In ANY game, this sortof issue would not be acceptable to consumers and grounds for a refund.

In retrospect, I should of requested a refund. Rockstar is treating customers poorly.

The game itself is awesome but try to get it not off of Steam. Do not pirate it either.

reviewText:
Genre: Third-person Shooter

Summary: One night, in December 2001, Max Payne, an undercover officer, answers a call to a lead that he hopes will to the murderers that killed his family. In his pursuit of vengeance, Max finds himself a embroiled in a conspiracy for power that stretches to involve criminal syndicates, pharmaceuticals, and the government.

Pros:
- The game's level-design is thought-out with its placement of enemies, hazards, and painkillers.
- The game's emphasis on strafing/dodging allows players to go in with guns blazing, due the generous amount of ammo, or strategically take out enemies with Bullet Time.
- The game subtly provides hints on how to progress within cut-scenes and stage environment.
- The presentation of the game is superb with its graphic novel cutscenes, noir-inspired narrative, and attention to detail (the amount of interactable, though limited, objects, A.I. conversations, etc.)
- The overall voice acting is impressive.
- The game has several gimmick levels that break up the action.
- The tutorial is short, concise, and encourages the players to experiment on their own.
- Completing game unlocks additional difficulty levels.

Cons:
- The game's pace slows down mid-game and doesn't pick back up until the end (about 8-10 hours of gameplay).
- The enemy A.I. approaches in a linear manner, repeatedly misses from afar, and occasionally kill themselves and their allies.
- The game's models are ugly and the lighting is terrible.
- The game has little to no music, what's there is average at best.
- Despite the impressive narrative, the plot itself action is cliché and silly due to being a pastiche of hard-boiled action flicks (the developers openly lampshade this).
- It is possible to get stuck in areas due to low ceilings or objects preventing backtracking.
- Some events may not happen and prevent progress (Ex: Vinnie Gognitti)

Neutral Points:
- The lack of zoom-in, outside of the sniper rifle, and aim assist creates depth by advocating strategic use of slow-down and meter management, however, this results in difficulties with shooting when the player runs out of Bullet-Time.
- There is a decent assortment of weapons, however, the majority of guns become obsolete as the game progresses due to either low damage or hit-stun.
- The nightmare sequences are unnerving and possess a chilling atmosphere, thanks to the voice clips, however, the platforming bits feel forced and have silly aesthetics.
- Save-scumming is possible.

reviewText:
Playing Max Payne a dozen of year after it was originally published wasn't a pleasant experience.

Let's disregard the horrible faces expressions, and let's think about its gameplay only: Max Payne is a trial and error cluster♥♥♥♥.

There's a huge amount of situations where enemies just wait for the player behind a door, ready to fire with their grenade launcher, or where enemies get to headshot the player with their shotgun from the other side of the room.
Halfway through, enemies don't get harder by design, but they just get double or triple their HP, so that to kill them you'll need 3 sniper rifle headshot and a couple of M79 shots just to be sure.

I'm aware of the fact that this was just their first attempt, but it is not that funny.
To the point that, if it was my call, there would have never been any sequel... :D

reviewText:
Story pros and cons:

+Deep story filled with some of the best narration I've heard- props to Remedy
+Comic style cutscenes are unique and help give an artistic vision to the story
+ Chilling concept revolving around the murder of his wife and child due to madmen on a drug called Valkyr
+ Character cracks some light-hearted jokes even in his time of desperation making the situation for the player more comfortable and helps with character development

-The jokes that Max Payne gives sometimes makes it hard to take him seriously
-Disturbing drug induced sequences
-Plot ending was somewhat anti-climatic and the last part was compared to the rest of the game too easy (not even considered a boss fight)
-Some character voices are annoying to say the least




Gamplay pros and cons:

+Bullet time is a an interesting and well designed mechanic
+Large selection of weaponry
+State of the art (for its time) particle system when bullets impact objects
+Interaction with objects provides immersion
+Weapons are sorted nicely in the upper part of the screen and fits with the rest of the UI.
+Enemies have conversations and sometimes interact with Payne's actions

-Some weapons are underpowered such as the shotguns (excluding the jackhammer), especially the dual barrel shotgun
-Sniper rifles are almost useless because enemies even on the easiest difficulty are extremly accurate with weapons like shotguns and uzi's and most of the areas in this game aren't large enough to make use of it
- Grenades have a deadly area of effect, even standing a few metres away from the blast you're lucky not to have a large chunk of your health taken away.
- Enemies are insanly accurate with the weapons, sometimes they'll use shotguns and manage to hit you from several metres away continously and destroy you with them. The player however somehow can't manage to kill enemies with a dual barrel shotgun at close range. Go figure!
-Uzi's do more damage close range than shotguns!? *scratches head* they can also take multiple enemies out so once you get the Uzi the shotguns become almost instantly unreliable
-Bosses are just buffed up in terms of health, they don't provide any interesting mechanics or tactic behind them. Some of the bosses are so ridicolous that even with multiple headshots, blasts from grenades etc still won't kill them on the easiest difficulty.
-Easiest difficulty is for some reason stupidly hard. I can't tell you how many times I've died and had my trigger finger on the quick saves.
-No auto saves.




Sound pro's and cons:

+Great gun sound effects
+Narration is crisp and clear considering its age
+Somewhat humerous death sounds
+Memmorable Soundtrack

-Lack of sound options means that you can't adjust the volume of the voice, sound effects and music seperatly
-Voice during comic style cutscenes are louder than in game
-No voice/music sound problems on Windows 7 and 8 requires you to go through the trouble of patching it.

Overall this game offers what looks like a simple plot which is executed rather well and complex and the narration is on par with Alan Wake which is also made by Remedy, I wholeheartedly recommend you go play that game over this one if you're looking for a very strong voice narration driven game because while this one provides that, it does so at the cost of mediocre gameplay, fustrating difficulty, absurd bosses and unbalanced weaponry. I haven't played Max Payne 2 yet so I can't recommend that game over this one.

With all that being said, I give the game a fair score of 6.5/10. There's fun to be had here, just remember that this game has aged and not necessarily in a good way.

The words I was typing sat on the screen like corpses bobbing in the harbor. Writing the review was the only way to finish what I had started. The game had my own name on it. My twisted, constipated grin staring back at me. I knew that playing this game would tear my soul apart. It was the only way I would have it.

My expierence with Max Payne before playing this game was a short stint on Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne when I was younger. Although I liked it alot, I never thought to revisit it or explore the series. With the games now being so cheap here on Steam I decided to give them a full playthrough each.
To sum up how I feel about this game, I'd find it hard to not recommend it. Yes the visuals have dated, but not to the extent that it looks ugly. The game offers all modern resolutions and run (at least for me) as smooth as butter.
Infact the only real issue I had with the game in terms of running it was a sound bug with was easily fixed with a small player created patch, it's likely you'll have to do the same.

Gameplay wise, it's a run of the mill third person shooter. The real sell point of this game aside from it's story is the bullet time ability. One click of a button and you'll enter bullet time, being able to perform rolls, jumps and dodges. It's not just a gimmick either, the game's high difficulty means you'll have to make use of it, but that's okay because it feels so smooth and natural to pull off bullet time kills.

The story and character of Max Payne is the other real catch here. Max is troubled, his deep poetic self expression through the game is well placed and well wrote. You'll find him describing just about everything you come across of note with a clever, noir style of depressive reckoning. The story is one of vengence, it's not out of place and keeps the action following nicely.

I would highly recommend giving this game ago. It's dated sure, but not to the point where you can't enjoy it.
I love this. I grew up playing it so finding it on steam was great. The only problem was going through the compatibilty and sound patcher
One of my favorite games of all time!

I rarely review games and only do so when I really REALLY enjoy the title.

I've known about Max Payne for years, I've watched my brother play it over 8 years ago and actually picked it up before. I didn't play much of it because I remember having some difficulties.

Fast forward to 2 days ago- See Max Payne on sale for like 3 bucks. That's a deal for any game, I'll give it a shot.

I got news for you, this game is incredible. It's one long action movie that is intricate and leaves you like a junkie looking for more Valkyr. Have you seen Max Payne the movie?? Yes? No? Either way, forget that movie- Play the game and you will NOT regret it.

As Max Payne, you get put into a tragic situation that only your guns can solve. You work your way up, and just when you think you've reached the top- You realize you've only scratched the surface.

Like I said before, there's the incredible story followed by great controls that make sense. Slow-Mo feature that works like bread and butter. The game IS challenging, if you're thinking slow mo makes stuff easy- you're wrong. Great length- Not long enough where you just want to get it done, not short enough where you feel like you've been gypped out of your cash.

The graphics are dated- The game was released almost 14 years ago on the MAX-FX engine. It's what you would expect from a game released in 2001. The faces on these characters are also priceless- taking and giving damage yields grimacing results that has it's own charm.

To sum up- The game's great- About 75% of the way through the game, I turned it off- Went to the steam store and bought Max Payne 2 and 3. I couldn't get enough. If you're a fan of the noir genre, this is for you. If you're a fan of action, this is for you, if you play fps and think that third person shooters wouldnt suit you, you're wrong- this game is for you. If you want to feel nostalgic and get a warm christmassy NYC vibe- THIS GAME IS FOR YOU.

9.5/10 Loses half a point for the lack of diverse weaponry- I feel like I only got stuff that got the job done, but on the other hand- I am just a NYC copper. You get pretty much whatever a cop would get. (With the exception of an M79)

Max Payne 2 is done downloading- I wont waste any more time writing this up!
Absolute classic and has aged remarkably well in the last 11 years. With the threequel round the corner, it's definitely worth revisiting.

When playing MP1 on Vista or Windows 7, 2 problems appear:
Most of the music, cut-scene sounds and game effects are missing
The mouse starts stuttering or lagging, making the gameplay unplayable
A combination of both
These are well known issues, unfortunately, it's very unlikely that Rockstar will ever launch a patch fixing this game, so here there are some workarounds you can try to fix the game:
FIXING THE SOUND: Thanks to Darkje who wrote a batch file for converting the game raw music/sounds to unsigned byte format, most of you will be able to enjoy the game w/o any problems. Download it here, along with the language files (if you want to) and don't forget to thank him (+rep is always nice): http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=848215
MOUSE LAG FIX #1: If you suffer from mouse lagging before or after installing the soundpatch, some users have reported that turning off mouse acceleration in your mouse control panel should do the trick. The drawback on this step is that only a few people will have a mouse with its own control panel.

NOTE: Thompaine suggests that If you don't have a special mouse with it's own control program
date: you can go into the "Mouse" control panel (Win7 classic CP) and uncheck the box labeled "Enhance pointer precision" under the "Pointer Options" tab"
recommended: which helped him after installing the patch (Thank you!)\nMOUSE LAG FIX #2: Go to your Max Payne folder and run maxpayne.exe in compatibility mode for Windows 95. Don't try to launch the game from the exe itself as it won't work. Launch the game from Steam as usual"

Max Payne, is a unique creation. A highly difficult third person shooter, that is extremely dark in it's gritty and noir atmosphere. The game would be nigh impossible if it were not for the bullet time mechanic; which allows you to dodge in slow motion to avoid bullets (and retaliate). Clocking into 7 hours, you'll be blasting your way through Max's bitter story. The movement and shooting mechanics are fluid and allow  freedom of movement during combat. The story and level is expertly woven together with intersections of narrated graphic novel in a truly noir fashion. The game certainly shows it's age in this time. Though the story and atmosphere is timeless, the game's graphics and stiff animations certainly show it's age. This deducts slightly from the overall atmosphere of the game and graphic-addicts may find Max Payne less immersive.

Overall Max Payne is a excellent and unique experience, although the age may affect the immersion, the quality of the writing will never fade.

If you're into gritty crime drama and solid action-shooter mechanics don't pass this up!"

reviewText:
Even at 2013's standards, Max Payne is an enjoyable romp. With a great story, fun gunplay accompanied with the awesome revolutionary matrix-esque gameplay mechanics, it's 10 hours game time is a joy to blast through.
The presentation of the game is quite stellar, especially with the comic-style storytelling, which I was pleasantly surprised to enjoy this style of storytelling.

MP has its flaws however. The frequent interactions of objects that initates a cut-scene can annoyingly break the adrenaline flow, and the saving system can be quite infurating, if you've forgotten to manually save the game by pressing a specific key.

Small flaws aside, Max Payne is still a great, fun game.

Recommended for newcomers to the series indeed. You may have sound issues during gameplay using current Windows operating systems, but thankfully there is a great fan patch that fixes the issue perfectly, so definitely grab that.

For some reason, I got to play Max Payne after all these years (it's 2014). A enjoyable, though somewhat dated third person shooter. You play as Max Payne, a NYPD-turned-DEA. The reason why? His wife and baby daughter was killed by druggies in the opening act of the game. The game's story is intriuging, as it deals with gangster's, betrayed cops, a secret society, and a corporate conspiracy, as well as Max's ultimate battle of fighting for his own well-being, all in very stylized comic book cutscences. Gameplay is a bit rough around the edges. Max Payne utilizes a bullet-time mechanic (Which you slow down time to dodge bullets akin to the matrix). Which helps alot- because you will have problems playing this as a straight laced 3rd person shooter. The aiming reticule is a primary offender of this, due to it being a small white dot in the middle of the screen. While it does help with immersion, it also makes it hard to aim at times. Thankfully, the game does have auto aim option, so it helps at times. The graphics- It's a game from 2001 so I can't say anything much- except the max payne model is scary. If I had rate it, it's a 8/10

Awesome Third Person Shooter.

Max Payne is, in some ways, a very unique game, and in many other ways it is just another third person shooter.

It really depends on how you look at it. Stylistically, Max Payne is very engaging simply because you don't really see a lot of video games in a 'Noir'-kind of setting; I really have never played a game that is anything like Max Payne! If Noir is your thing and you love yourself some of those 'bloody revenge' stories in which one guy shoots his way through Mafia goons, you will probably not be disappointed by Max Payne...

... That is, if you are sure that you can handle old-school shooters. For someone like me, this game aged very well actually, since I do not mind these older shooting mechanics which simply involve you evading fire rather than covering from it. It's a very simplistic game in that sense; don't expect any sort of depth. That's not a fault of the game, but I have talked to players who could not get into the game because they thought these mechanics lacked the intricacies of newer shooting games, like cover-mechanics and upgradable weapons. Not to mention, death is inevitable in Max Payne, mostly because Max can die in just a few gunshots (it's 'realistic' that way) and because he does not regenerate health on his own, so expect to be overwhelmed by enemies more often than not. Some may call it frustrating, but I call it challenging!

Players who grew up playing games that force you to constantly quick save, quick load and just abuse the terrain to get cheap shots at enemies will enjoy this game no matter what, I would say. There isn't any variation in gameplay, all you do is search for ammo and health, and then shoot bad guys - Nothing more, nothing less. Either way, Max Payne is a classic.

An instant classic, Max Payne delivers on all fronts. An incredible shooter experience, with mechanics such as bullet time, which works so well with the game. The story itself is also displayed in comic panels, rather than cutscenes, which is something I've not seen in another game yet.

The story, which is more often lost in newer shooters remains very strong in this game. While playing, I felt as though this was a personal battle, and remained on edge for the next part of the story. Max's character is great fun to play, and it's extremely disappointing to see the third Payne deviating from it's roots so much.

This game, like its sequels, has potentially, the best writing, narrative, and dialogue of any game series to date. The game play is a perfect mix of fast and fun, but is also incredibly unforgiving. Make serious use of the quicksaves and quickloads or you'e gonna have a bad time. The PC version might have some issues like missing audio, but you can find easy fixes online.

The story is dark, perfectly told, and complimented with Max Payne's incredibly blunt, pessimistic narration over graphic novel-esque panels. It's long enough to hold your interest all the way through and just short enough to avoid any boring filler content. Every second of the game feels neccesary for the bigger picture.

Obviously the graphics are not on par with todays releases but it does have a very unique style that genuinely adds to the charm of the game. And of course the game features some of the best pause screen music I've ever heard.

+ Seriously Fun Gameplay
+ Difficulty balanced out with quicksaves
+ Incredible Music
+ Greatest writing ever
+ Enthralling Story
+ Monotony mixed up with set pieces (flashbacks etc.)
+ Voice acting is perfect

- Enemys accuracy with a shotgun is ♥♥♥♥ING ridiculous, borderline unfair
- Sound issue (mutes most audio in game) occurs for some people, fix -->     http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1858303

reviewText: sick story, great gameplay, a classic

It's around seven hours long, but that doesn't stop the game from having its story told eloquently. Don't let its short gameplay threaten you, it's absolutely worth it.

In my opinion, it all started to get interesting once you see the first noticeable example of how Valkyr, this new, hot commodity drug, affects people. Even Max gets to see why it's all the rage...

After dealing with mafia bosses and partnerships, in the end, Max's ultimate goal is to find whoever was responsible for trafficking Valkyr. This game does well to end things neatly, instead of leaving loose ends; things that could never be answered.

I don't know about the replay value, but like books and movies, you'll connect something you hadn't noticed before if you do choose to pick it up again.

There's lots of cute little easter eggs too, interesting aspects of the game you might run across while playing it.
If film-noir and detectives gives you a massive boner, play this masterpiece.

My expierence with Max Payne before playing this game was a short stint on Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne when I was younger. Although I liked it alot, I never thought to revisit it or explore the series. With the games now being so cheap here on Steam I decided to give them a full playthrough each.
To sum up how I feel about this game, I'd find it hard to not recommend it. Yes the visuals have dated, but not to the extent that it looks ugly. The game offers all modern resolutions and run (at least for me) as smooth as butter.
Infact the only real issue I had with the game in terms of running it was a sound bug with was easily fixed with a small player created patch, it's likely you'll have to do the same.

Gameplay wise, it's a run of the mill third person shooter. The real sell point of this game aside from it's story is the bullet time ability. One click of a button and you'll enter bullet time, being able to perform rolls, jumps and dodges. It's not just a gimmick either, the game's high difficulty means you'll have to make use of it, but that's okay because it feels so smooth and natural to pull off bullet time kills.

The story and character of Max Payne is the other real catch here. Max is troubled, his deep poetic self expression through the game is well placed and well wrote. You'll find him describing just about everything you come across of note with a clever, noir style of depressive reckoning. The story is one of vengence, it's not out of place and keeps the action following nicely.

I would highly recommend giving this game ago. It's dated sure, but not to the point where you can't enjoy it.

Awesome Third Person Shooter.

Max Payne is, in some ways, a very unique game, and in many other ways it is just another third person shooter.

It really depends on how you look at it. Stylistically, Max Payne is very engaging simply because you don't really see a lot of video games in a 'Noir'-kind of setting; I really have never played a game that is anything like Max Payne! If Noir is your thing and you love yourself some of those 'bloody revenge' stories in which one guy shoots his way through Mafia goons, you will probably not be disappointed by Max Payne...

... That is, if you are sure that you can handle old-school shooters. For someone like me, this game aged very well actually, since I do not mind these older shooting mechanics which simply involve you evading fire rather than covering from it. It's a very simplistic game in that sense; don't expect any sort of depth. That's not a fault of the game, but I have talked to players who could not get into the game because they thought these mechanics lacked the intricacies of newer shooting games, like cover-mechanics and upgradable weapons. Not to mention, death is inevitable in Max Payne, mostly because Max can die in just a few gunshots (it's 'realistic' that way) and because he does not regenerate health on his own, so expect to be overwhelmed by enemies more often than not. Some may call it frustrating, but I call it challenging!

Players who grew up playing games that force you to constantly quick save, quick load and just abuse the terrain to get cheap shots at enemies will enjoy this game no matter what, I would say. There isn't any variation in gameplay, all you do is search for ammo and health, and then shoot bad guys - Nothing more, nothing less. Either way, Max Payne is a classic.

(Spoilers)  I would think with my history of video games that I would have played this classic sooner but lastly I haven't.  I recently beat the game and am generally pleased with it.  For the time it was released (2001) It was impressive.  Playing it now some of the graphics seem dated, especially the character models, however that doesn’t mean it’s a bad game.  The story is excellent and is what kept me playing through wanting to know how it all ended.  The “cut scenes” were a nice change from typical video games, being done in a graphic novel type of way.  The cinematics we’re innovative at the time and to this day still hold up for some pretty cool moments (that final helicopter crash).  Game play was pretty fun, the main thing being the slow motion bullet time.  It had a very Matrix feel and made the game play that much more fun.  That being said the big problem I had with the game was the difficulty.  I don’t mind a games difficulty if it’s the players skill and not the games fault.  This was not the case, I found it extremely frustrating the amount of health lost when hit with enemy fire yet the amount of shots it took to take down that enemy.  It only added to the frustration when I would die having to start back at the beginning, even more annoying was the un-skipable cut scenes that I saw countless times.  I found myself hitting escape and saving my game after every group of enemies I killed.  This for me really ruined the immersion of the game which, for a game like this I felt was important.  Maybe not everyone had this problem and it could just be me.  That being said after thinking about replay value, sound, story, gameplay, graphics, everything I could think of I would give this game a 7.5/10

Max Payne touches my cold, lonely heart like a well-placed punch to my mouth would have made my ex-braces rip through my lip tissue. The one-man-war Max led in his quest for retribution is timeless, deeply enhanced by the secluded atmosphere of a New York winter storm, its sketchy comic book presentation and somber music. Many recognized this game for its innovative bullet-time effect but I remember it as a reminder of what a sole man can do through sheer willpower (those painkillers don't heal wounds!). Please don't take the film version as reference.

Max Payne is a third person shooter from 2001. You play Max Payne a NYPD detective that comes home to his wife and baby killed by a group of druggies. The only clue he has in a V symbol. Standing for Valkyr. He quits the NYPD and becomes an undercover detective. From there you get loads of shooting and running and great writing.

I am still amazed that this game has aged so well. Sure it isn't as pretty as it used to be, but the gameplay is still solid and the challenge is still there. It's a fast paced run and gun kind of shooter. You get loads of ammo and have a very small amount of health. Depending on the gun you could die from five to two shots. The level design is linear, but put togfether very well.

The only complaint I could have is that there isn't a HUGE amount of replay value. Although I think this could depend on the player. If you don't usually care to go through a story multiple times then you will probably only get six to eight hours in this game. I bet there are other players that have put in 60 hours due to higher difficulties and modes like A New York Minute" mode.

Max Payne is still worth buying to this day. The price they ask sweetens the deal. Especially if you buy the bundle that include Max Payne 2."

Still the superb game I remember it being nearly a decade and a half ago. Although it definitely looks a lot better on PC now than it did on Xbox when I originally played it. But I must be honest and confess I did use my PS4 controller with it while using Xpadder. The controls were always smooth and transferred over from PC really well. The only technical problems I had were with the audio. Certain sounds wouldn't always work. and This game is definitely still the same ole' difficult game it once was. If it weren't for the quick save feature which I used abundantly, I would have been bald from tearing out my hair. The Story wasn't as straightforward and linear as the actually progression from one task to the next was. There was a couple of twists" but none all too much
date: and I didn't ever feel any hate towards the main antagonist lady as I should've. But nonetheless
recommended: the story was enjoyable. Especially the few times where Max Payne was as high as a kite or hallucinating in his dreams. Those are the missions you will always remember no matter the years away from this game. I'm so glad I bought this game along with the other Max Payne's as part of the Amazon sale bundle. No regrets at all after spending the nearly exact 15 hours it took to complete this game. Definitely proud to say I played through the epic game that is Max Payne. 9/10"

reviewText:
Max Payne is a bonafide and award winning noir classic released in 2001. The game centers around a NYPD cop working undercover in the Valkyr-drug smuggling mafia seeking answers after he got his family killed. As the story unravels, Max becomes the most wanted guy by the mafia and the NYPD and discover what is hiding behind the drug Valkyr.

The story is presented to the player using comic novels artifacts which sometimes resembles Frank Miller's Sin City. Cutscenes are entertaining to watch and sucks you into it with a noir narrative. I wish Max Payne got his own comic book, because the writing is second to none immersive. There is a heavy influence of nordic mythos which adds to the bigger picture.

I love the level design. Although is set mostly in a stormy, snowy and dark NY or inside some buildings, it nevers gets repetitive. You'll be looking all over the place for clues, guns and painkillers. Max Payne has one of the best level design I've ever seen in any game. You'll never forget about those nightmare levels and shootings at the Ragna Rock night club.

The music is beautiful. It has a dark and dense mood to it, the one you'd expect from detective stories. The synth sounds go really with the ambient sounds.

The gameplay is absolutely fun. The game introduces an innovative (at the time) bullet time and bullet dodge mechanics. This is a hard game, although there is some automatic health regen don't expect miracles. You'll be craving for painkillers through out the whole game. Also, a word of advice, DON'T save if you're not sure if you're still in the middle of a bullet fest.

I can assure you the game aged gracefully.

Writing a positive review about an award winning game that eventually became the cornerstone of the 2000's age of gaming feels just like another brick in the wall. It's just another one in the bag of thousand positive reviews Max Payne got through the years.

A must have for ANY gamer.
If this game was a banana........ it would be a good banana

Max Payne is a really unique game, a rare gaming gem.

Back in 2001 it was a revolutionary game.

You are Max Payne, a man with nothing to lose. Your family is murdered by drug addicts, you are deep undercover in the underworld of New York. Then, your cover is blown, and the cops thinks you are one of the bad guys.

The game itself is a 3rd person shooter, with it´s best feature being the ability to slow down time. This feature added depth to the vicious shootouts, and the destruction caused by the bullets could be apreciated in detail.
Simply put, there were nothing like that around.
It borrowed many elements from The Matrix, including slow motion action sequences and many of its locations.

You just have to keep moving and keep shooting every single enemy (there is one scort mission, but it´s fairly short and thankfully not frustating at all), It could be repetitive in theory, but the shootings are so fun it never gets old.
Dodging bullets while firing your duals berettas couldn´t be more rewarding.

The story is surprisingly deep for a game of it´s kind. It involves drugs, infanticide, madness, evend the russian mafia plays it´s part, and high echelon corporate conspiracy. It´s just awesome, and told in a very dark tone.
Ultimately, it´s a tale of revenge of a broken man, alone and desperate, with no higher moral, no savior cause or anything.

It aged very well. The mechanics are still fun, the graphics might seem a bit bulky and outdated, but there are some really good textures and nice particle effects that still makes it good looking in movement. Also, any cheap PC can run it with max settings without problems.

If you dig deep, you can also find some very interesting mods, adding weapons and levels that explore more of the great shooting mechanics.


10/10
